headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the CMS Energy 2015 Year-End Results and Outlook Call. The earnings news release issued earlier today and the presentation used in this webcast are available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section.
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the CMS Energy 2015 Year-End Results and Outlook Call. The earnings news release issued earlier today and the presentation used in this webcast are available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]
Just a reminder, there will be a rebroadcast of this conference call today, beginning at 12 p.m. Eastern Time, running through February 11th. This presentation is also being webcast and is available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. DV Rao, Vice President and Treasurer, Financial Planning and Investor Relations.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. With me are, John Russell, President and Chief Executive Officer; Patty Poppe, Senior Vice President of Distribution Operations Engineering and Transmission; and Tom Webb, Executive Vice Presiden
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. With me are, John Russell, President and Chief Executive Officer; Patty Poppe, Senior Vice President of Distribution Operations Engineering and Transmission; and Tom Webb, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings for more information regarding the risks and other factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially. This presentation also includes non-GAAP measures. Reconciliations of these measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure are included in appendix and also posted on our website.
Now, let me turn the call over to John.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, DV, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on our year-end earnings call.I'll begin the presentation with a review of our last year's results and this year's priorities before turning the call over to Patty for a review our unique cus
componenttext:
Thanks, DV, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on our year-end earnings call.
I'll begin the presentation with a review of our last year's results and this year's priorities before turning the call over to Patty for a review our unique customer and investor model. Tom will provide the financial results and outlook, than as usual, close with the Q&A.
2015 earnings per share were $1.89, up 7% from the prior year's actual result. We are raising our 2016 guidance to $1.99 to $2.02 per share. This is an increase of 5% to 7%, reflecting our predictable and consistent 5% to 7% performance year-over-year. Recently, our board approved a 7% dividend increase, raising it to $1.24 per share. This results in a competitive payout ratio of 62%. 
2015 was a record setting year. I'm most proud of our safety result, the best in our company's 130-year history. Our distribution minutes were the best in a decade, and the generation plant performance was the best ever. Customer satisfaction arose to first quartile for both residential, electric and gas customers. Since 2006, the company has achieved breakthrough performance. Safety incidents are down 79%, productivity is up 62%, outage minutes are down 34% and employee engagement is first quartile. I'm confident this performance will continue to drive the results you've been a custom to. These areas will continue to improve and we look to other initiatives to improve service and reduce costs.
Michigan currently has a strong Energy law in the books. The law supports 10% renewable energy, energy efficiency standards, forward-looking test years and a retail open access capped at 10%. As we would expect, the governor's focus on the water issue influent. His attention should be focused on helping the people of Flint, a city that we serve. In the meantime, we expect the energy committees in the House and Senate to continue their work. We expect an updated energy law will be passed by the first half of this year. But keep in mind and this is important, the update to the Energy law is not in our plan. In fact, we have not included any law-related capital investments in our plan.
For 2016, we plan to continue our breakthrough performance. Operationally, we'll continue to make safety a top priority for employees, customers and the communities we serve. Again this year, we are planning cost reductions to our industry-leading performance. We will continue to execute our strategy and deliver the same addictive and financial performance as you have in the past.
Now I would like to welcome and turn the call over to Patty.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. We're especially pleased to announced today that we are raising our guidance beginning in 2017, to 6% to 8% from 5% to 7%. This reflects the increase in capital investment to $17 billion over the next 10 years, from $15.5 billion as annou
componenttext:
Thank you, John. We're especially pleased to announced today that we are raising our guidance beginning in 2017, to 6% to 8% from 5% to 7%. This reflects the increase in capital investment to $17 billion over the next 10 years, from $15.5 billion as announced last week. As most of you know, we've been delivering 7% growth each year for over a decade. While this increase reflects the higher level of capital expending, it demonstrates our comfort in continuing 7% growth in the midpoint of our new range for years ahead.
You might ask, why we're not raising the guidance for 2016. We still have opportunities to reinvest O&M and to strength our liability and a higher level of capital investment does fully kick-in until later this year.
Our confidence in the sustainability of our premier earnings growth rate is reflection of our business model where we self fund a large portion of the capital investment growth for our customers. We do this by reducing our costs and avoiding the need for equity with the dissociated dilution. This model permits us to keep base rate increases at below inflation resulting in sustainable growth.
Both our core and increased level of capital investment are targeted to improve customer service, enhance reliability and among several other things, increase affordability by providing for cost reductions. The $1.5 billion increase in capital investment includes: $800 million in the next 5 years to replace aging infrastructure and improve service reliability. It also includes another $700 million in the following 5 years to provide for the clean energy resources we believe will be needed to meet the Clean Power Plan in the most economical way.
We still have considerable opportunities for even more capital investments. Those opportunities included replacing PPAs when they expire. These opportunities alone represent for additional 2,000 megawatts of capacity, and around another $2 billion of capital investment. We also need to do more with our gas infrastructure and modernization of the grid. And likely, we'll make further capital investment for renewables.  None of this is attributable to the update in the 2008 energy loss. These investments will be required with or without a change to that loss.
In the past, we reminded you that we've been able to reduce our cost for most of our peers cost. Our track record is evident of our ability to be more productive for our customers and our plans for the future continue this. There based on good business decisions could have already been made the permit ongoing legacy cost reductions, productivity gains as the workforce turns over, the shift from cold to gas generation, the introduction of smart meters and the elimination of waste. As we improve customer quality to better work processes, we'll save on overtime cost and temporary workers by simply doing it right the first time.
For example, nearly 1/3 of the time when you're old trucks on a job, something goes wrong. The parts are on the truck or other parties that need to be on site aren't always on time. We're aggressively pursuing these opportunities to improve quality for our customers.
For 2014 and 2015, we reduced our cost by 4%, and by 2018 expect to have reduced our cost by at least 10%. While our model is successful with our cost reductions, it helps equally at sales grow. Our team believes that our sales growth will be about 2% this year and in the future, but we plan conservatively. For the purposes of executing our model, we're assuming growth of 1%.
We put all of this together and end up with the attractive business model for our customers, with their level of service and affordability improves every year, and the same model permits us to do deliver 6% to 8% earnings growth beginning in 2017. It's a reaffirmation of our confidence in our ability to deliver earnings per share and dividend growth at a level that you have come to expect.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Patty. Let's look at the business for 2015, 2016 and beyond. As you can see here, in 2015, our earnings grew by $0.12 or 20% on a weather-normalized basis. We achieved with these consistent results despite the fact that December was the warmest on
componenttext:
Thanks, Patty. Let's look at the business for 2015, 2016 and beyond. As you can see here, in 2015, our earnings grew by $0.12 or 20% on a weather-normalized basis. We achieved with these consistent results despite the fact that December was the warmest on record, exceeding by 10% the previous record in 1923. For December, Michigan was 37% warmer than normal.
As we mentioned last week, we offset the mild weather and the couple of year-end storms by achieving a tax settlement in Michigan, putting off some donations to our foundation and other improvements. With a mild weather bills was substantially lower-than-expected, which is helpful to our customers, but it also results in lower uncollectible accounts. So weather was not normal, dragging down profits. Our commitment to manage the work was normal. No excuses from us. We're pleased to have continued great progress for our customers, and once again delivered on 7% growth for our owners.
We achieved all of our financial targets for 2015. These included strong capital investment; healthy balance sheet ratios; dramatic customer pricing decreases; robust operating cash flow growth; top end of guidance EPS growth; and as announced last week, another substantial increase in our dividend.
For 2016, we're pleased to have raised our guidance to reflect 5% to 7% growth on top of high-end 2015 results, which were at the top end of guidance for 2015. We continue to build success upon success, no recess here. While our electric and gas rate cases primarily reflect capital investment, they also permit us to flow through productivity improvements to our customers. This is one of the elements of our model that makes high-end earnings growth sustainable. It's also noteworthy that 3 quarters of the rate change impact already has either been authorized or self implemented. And let's not forget the Ferrari -- excuse me, as Patty would say that Tesla in the garage. After all, the Tesla does 0 to 60 in 2.8 seconds, that's faster than the Ferrari spider.
At DIG, we have long-term energy contracts locked in providing stable results. And with a large portion of capacity available, we continue to have read for upside. Here is our sensitive slide that they provide each quarter to assist with assessing our prospects. There is not a lot of news, there seldom is. You can see that with a reasonable planning assumptions and with robust risk mitigation, the probability of large variances from our plan are minimized. And while we look forward to the 2008 Energy Law update, our plan does not reflect any of the upside associated with this.
Our cash flow and earnings growth are driven by our capital investment program. With our recent announcement increasing capital investment by $1.5 billion to $17 billion over the next 10 years, earnings and cash flow growth will accelerate. Starting in 2017, we're lifting EPS growth guidance to 6% to 8%, bracketing historic growth at 7%. The higher investment kicks in for '17, and we have more O&M reinvestment accomplished yet this year.
We still have opportunities in excess of $3 billion to add to our plan in the future. For the last 12 years, our gross operating cash flow has been growing by more than $100 million each year. Since 2004, it has increased from $353 million a year to $1.9 billion. Over the next 5 years, it should growth about $800 million to $2.7 billion, cash
Our net operating cash flow also grows by $0.5 billion. This reflects capital investment recovery, aggressive working capital management and little help from Uncle Sam. Newborn's depreciation is welcomed, funding part of our increase capital investment and preserving NOLs for future shelter. Amazingly, I have to admit -- amazingly, we may go over 7 years instead of 5, with no need for dilutive equity.
While the benefit of bonus depreciation is about 1/3 of our CapEx lift of $1.5 billion, it's half of the rate base increases for the 2016 to 2020 period. With the left, billing CapEx in behind the Jackson plant purchase, which was accelerated to December 2015 from '16, and our incremental pension contribution rate base rises $1.2 billion, one half of which is funded by bonus depreciation.
This results in an upside to earnings of $0.02 or 1% a year and that starts in 2017.
Here is our new report card, we anticipate another good year of 2016 and an even stronger year in 2017. With no big debts and robust risk mitigation, our model sows our customers and you well. New companies are able to deliver top end earnings growth while substantially improving value and service for customers.
Value for customers is what has made our plan so sustainable. Here is how we do it. Reasonable cost reductions of 2% to 3%, and service of sales growth at 1%, and other tools that avoid dilution worth another 2%, allow us to self fund 5 points to 6 points of earnings per share growth. Customer base rate increases can be at or below the level of inflation. These very same model at cell phones investment for customers also allows us to self fund a large portion of our capital needs. The model has worked for a decade. It's our plan for the next 5 years. And that's making it attractive for investors and customers and consequently, sustainable.
John Patty and I will be visiting Boston and New York next week and we look forward to answering your questions about these plans, so until then, Steve would you please open the lines to take some questions today.

componenttextpreview: Really, what we needed to do is invest the capital. I mean, this is what we talked about, I think, in the last call when we announced Patty's succession plan. At the day is -- we can't wait for the lot to wait done for us to make investment for our custom
componenttext: Really, what we needed to do is invest the capital. I mean, this is what we talked about, I think, in the last call when we announced Patty's succession plan. At the day is -- we can't wait for the lot to wait done for us to make investment for our customers. And that was clear as we were moving forward. So as we increase the amount, bonus depreciation obviously took a little bit of that way, but it certainly allowed us to continue to grow at even a higher rates than we had before, but also keep our customer rates at or below rate of inflation. And that's something that we finally decided to do. And as Patty mentioned in her presentation, we also have increased operating costs, particularly, in the O&M area, that we're seeing the results that our customers want from service and quality. And that's really where we're going after. So now is the time, and obviously with our performance, we think bracketing it between 6% to 8% is the right approach going forward.

componenttext: And with our operating plan, we have increased confidence in our ability to control cost and make those capital investments, many of them which helped enable those cost reductions that protect our customers from any kind of rates spikes. So we feel very good about the total combined effort to achieve 6% to 8%.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I mean, as Tom pointed out in his slides, there are opportunities of $3 billion on top of what we already talked about. So -- but part of that has to come out of not only the law, but I think what's going to come out of that regardless of the law is what happens with Michigan's response to the Clean Power Plan. I mean that really is going to drive what we do as far as meeting that plan, and those opportunities are in there. And as Tom mentioned in his presentation 2, we've got some PPAs that are going to expiring over the next 10 years or within the next 10 years, that when you to look at 2 and see how we're going to replace those.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Just to add one thing, Patty mention just a minute ago, the robust nature of the model and the cost reductions that come out of some of the investment. Don't forget of the $3 billion opportunity in CapEx we just talked about, could be the $2 billion is what John just said, related to these PPAs, we can replace our PPAs cheaper than the PPAs. We can build plants cheaper that what the PPAs today. So therefore, the model really works, if and when those come in. We still keep our base rate growth down and we still can grow little further.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I think what's most important in all this discussion, we continued to do what we say we're going to do, consistent, predictable, regardless of what the guidance is, we tend to hit it, we have hit it every single year on top of actual results, whi
componenttext: And then I think what's most important in all this discussion, we continued to do what we say we're going to do, consistent, predictable, regardless of what the guidance is, we tend to hit it, we have hit it every single year on top of actual results, which I think separates us from some others.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. And you can see that when we call '11 or '12 of our data and comes with the press release. The sales were down and residential flat, commercials off a little bit, as you can see there, and industrial is off a little bit. Recall this, we act
componenttext:
Good question. And you can see that when we call '11 or '12 of our data and comes with the press release. The sales were down and residential flat, commercials off a little bit, as you can see there, and industrial is off a little bit. Recall this, we actually can't name the customer here, but we do have a customer who has spent most of the year getting a supply issue taken care of. And so they have actually dampened our sales through the year. They are not a big margin so it's not a big issue. They are starting to turn up already. And so their restoration is just getting back to where they used to be, and I suspect they're going to do better. We're kind of offset the negative with a plus this year, but here's the important part. I would tell you our internal data tells us that we're going to grow more than what we've shown you today. So very visually today 1% and then 4% on the industrial side, our internal data gives us higher numbers. We just don't believe in going out there with something that we can't deliver on. So we put in more conservative numbers. Here's what's going to drive the uptick. I think, by the way, residential and commercial are still be a little uneven, but I just call it flat.
Industrial side is coming around because we're seeing new companies hooking up new facilities, new businesses coming into the state and our existing businesses doing better. So for example, we've got a brick-maker, high-end brick maker, who is going to add 24 megawatts -- building the building and doing the work right now, so that's coming out. We see one of our automotive folks actually putting in new paint facilities and running more extended periods of time, that's another big chunk of megawatts coming in that wasn't there before. We see just a variety of people, particularly, on the food side, housing side, plastic and rubber sector and paper and paper product sector that are all giving us the size information about optics. So we see some good news and we're happy for that. But we'll tell you, 1% growth, we think will be quite good our model.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Second question, what happens to the model, if anything -- if we do come back to a period of rising gas prices, which we used to have, but haven't had for last several years, does that impact your model and your planning in anyway?
componenttext: Understood. Second question, what happens to the model, if anything -- if we do come back to a period of rising gas prices, which we used to have, but haven't had for last several years, does that impact your model and your planning in anyway?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I'd just tell you that these prices are phenomenal. And even if they did rise, and I admit if you look at it from this moment to the next moment a year from now say they did rise, sure, that's an increase, but people are looking at absolute bills, wri
componenttext: No, I'd just tell you that these prices are phenomenal. And even if they did rise, and I admit if you look at it from this moment to the next moment a year from now say they did rise, sure, that's an increase, but people are looking at absolute bills, writing checks. And when they look at where they were, even we had a substantial rise and they look at where they were just a few years ago, their situation, they compare gas for whether it's home heating or industrial or electric -- they compare that even with higher prices to alternatives, attractive. So we don't see that as a big issue, but I'll tell you again, if you saw the detail of our 5-year plans, you'd see that we had gas prices rising quite a bit. And even inside of that, our model still delivers what would tell you about with being able to keep base rates low, bills low if you can and also grow the business. So for us, we don't see an immediate concern.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just add there. One thing about the gas business just to remind everybody, we've got a substantial gas business, we're the fourth largest in the country, we've got the largest utility storage fields in the country. So at the end of the day when gas
componenttext: Let me just add there. One thing about the gas business just to remind everybody, we've got a substantial gas business, we're the fourth largest in the country, we've got the largest utility storage fields in the country. So at the end of the day when gas prices rise, we've had over 300 billion cubic feet of storage gas, both phase and working gas, that we can draw which really keeps us competitive and rising market. It tends to work the other way in a declining market, actually because the gas in the storage field tends to be a little bit higher price than the market. So it does give us a competitive advantage, makes us -- allows us to use our transmission system fully we're buying gas all through the year, which really helps our customers.

So I feel good about that, actually think the opportunities we have and as Patty talked about here with the growth rate and some of the other things we're talking about, are better than we've had in the past. And I'll turn it over to you, obviously, it's you're 5 years.

And so we are prepared. We have a good eye on water opportunities are to continue to make the model work. And so we are -- I would say, very optimistic about our future look here in the next 5 years to 10 years.

componenttextpreview: Well, the bilateral markets do a lot to tell you where you really are right now. Our sense is the energy markets got to some pretty good levels that we liked. So over the last couple of years, we locked in some long-term contracts. On the capacity markets
componenttext: Well, the bilateral markets do a lot to tell you where you really are right now. Our sense is the energy markets got to some pretty good levels that we liked. So over the last couple of years, we locked in some long-term contracts. On the capacity markets, we still see there is going to be some movement up and down. And we see in the ups there will be opportunity. You may recall from the past, we're not trying to wait for a peak and miss it. We're just in this capacity contracts as we get to a little bit better levels. So we were doing it in $1 and then $2 and $3, and we've done some recently in $3-plus zone, but we think there is still going to be some opportunities. We like having big available as a backup as they had to bid into our utility, but we also like the opportunity that win those markets rise a little bit, because people see a short fall in Zone 7. We can service this debt market and that's the upside of the $20 million and $40 million that shows on the slide.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, it looks like -- I leave you with the commission has -- the latest update is we're about at the capacity level, we're about 500-megawatt short for Zone 7 for this year, but based on 22,000 megawatts, that's in the noise. So really, I think the outlo
componenttext: Paul, it looks like -- I leave you with the commission has -- the latest update is we're about at the capacity level, we're about 500-megawatt short for Zone 7 for this year, but based on 22,000 megawatts, that's in the noise. So really, I think the outlook if you're thinking about the future, let's look at '17, and as you know, we're closing 7 plants in April of this year, there is some other activities that may occur based on the Clean Power Plan. So let's see what happens in '17, but right now Michigan's should be good for this year. I don't see that are the problem, but tonight about that line right now. And they're also that is not a lot of new plants being built. So really it's using the excess capacity up.

componenttext: So you can figure in our view by looking at that slide you just reviewed, we would not hold 90% of our capacity available for the long-term future, if we thought over time there was no opportunity for uptick in those prices.

So I know Julia and it would want to hear this, but we don't see a plan where you would expect to see our growth above 6% to 8%. And if that's not good news, that's just the way we think.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the CMS Energy 2015 Year-end Results and Outlook Call. The earnings news release issued earlier today and the presentation used in this webcast are available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section.
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the CMS Energy 2015 Year-end Results and Outlook Call. The earnings news release issued earlier today and the presentation used in this webcast are available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]
Just a reminder, there will be a rebroadcast of this conference call today, beginning at 12 p.m. Eastern Time, running through February 11th. This presentation is also being webcast and is available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. DV Rao, Vice President and Treasurer, Financial Planning and Investor Relations.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. With me are John Russell, President and Chief Executive Officer; Patti Poppe, Senior Vice President of Distribution Operations, Engineering and Transmission; and Tom Webb, Executive Vice Presiden
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. With me are John Russell, President and Chief Executive Officer; Patti Poppe, Senior Vice President of Distribution Operations, Engineering and Transmission; and Tom Webb, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings for more information regarding the risks and other factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially. This presentation also includes non-GAAP measures. Reconciliations of these measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the Appendix and also posted on our website.
Now, let me turn the call over to John.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, DV, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on our year-end earnings call.I'll begin the presentation with a review of last year's results and this year's priorities before turning the call over to Patti for a review of our unique cust
componenttext:
Thanks, DV, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on our year-end earnings call.
I'll begin the presentation with a review of last year's results and this year's priorities before turning the call over to Patti for a review of our unique customer and investor model. Tom will provide the financial results and outlook, then as usual, close with the Q&A.
2015 earnings per share were $1.89, up 7% from the prior year's actual result. We are raising our 2016 guidance to $1.99 to $2.02 per share. This is an increase of 5% to 7%, reflecting our predictable and consistent 5% to 7% performance year-over-year. Recently, our board approved a 7% dividend increase, raising it to $1.24 per share. This results in a competitive payout ratio of 62%. 
2015 was a record setting year. I'm most proud of our safety result, the best in our company's 130-year history. Our distribution minutes were the best in a decade, and the generation plant performance was the best ever. Customer satisfaction rose to first quartile for both residential, electric and gas customers. Since 2006, the company has achieved breakthrough performance. Safety incidents are down 79%, productivity is up 62%, outage minutes are down 34% and employee engagement is first quartile. I'm confident this performance will continue to drive the results you've been accustomed to. These areas will continue to improve, and we look to other initiatives to improve service and reduce costs.
Michigan currently has a strong energy law in the books. The law supports 10% renewable energy, energy efficiency standards, forward-looking test years and a retail open access capped at 10%. As you would expect, the Governor is focus on the water issue in Flint. His attention should be focused on helping the people of Flint, a city that we serve. In the meantime, we expect the energy committees in the House and Senate to continue their work. We expect an updated energy law will be passed by the first half of this year. But keep in mind and this is important, the update to the energy law is not in our plan. In fact, we have not included any law-related capital investments in our plan.
For 2016, we plan to continue our breakthrough performance. Operationally, we will continue to make safety a top priority for our employees, customers and the communities we serve. Again this year, we are planning cost reductions to our industry-leading performance. We will continue to execute our strategy and deliver the same predictable financial performance as we have in the past.
Now I would like to welcome and turn the call over to Patti.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. We're especially pleased to announced today, that we are raising our guidance, beginning in 2017 to 6% to 8% from 5% to 7%. This reflects the increase in capital investment to $17 billion over the next 10 years, from $15.5 billion as anno
componenttext:
Thank you, John. We're especially pleased to announced today, that we are raising our guidance, beginning in 2017 to 6% to 8% from 5% to 7%. This reflects the increase in capital investment to $17 billion over the next 10 years, from $15.5 billion as announced last week. As most of you know, we have been delivering 7% growth each year for over a decade. While this increase reflects the higher level of capital spending, it demonstrates our comfort in continuing 7% growth, the midpoint of our new range for years ahead.
You might ask, why we're not raising the guidance for 2016. We still have opportunities to reinvest O&M and to strengthen our reliability and the higher level of capital investment doesn't fully kick-in until later this year.
Our confidence in the sustainability of our premier earnings growth rate is a reflection of our business model, where we self-fund a large portion of the capital investment growth for our customers. We do this by reducing our cost and avoiding the need for block equity with the dissociated dilution. This model permits us to keep base rate increases at or below inflation, resulting in sustainable growth.
Both our core and increased level of capital investment are targeted to improve customer service, enhance reliability and among several other things, increase affordability by providing for cost reductions. The $1.5 billion increase in capital investment includes: $800 million in the next 5 years to replace aging infrastructure and improve service reliability. It also includes another $700 million in the following 5 years to provide for the clean energy resources, we believe, will be needed to meet the Clean Power Plan in the most economical way.
We still have considerable opportunities for even more capital investment. Those opportunities included replacing PPAs when they expire. These opportunities alone represent the need for an additional 2,000 megawatts of capacity and around another $2 billion of capital investment. We also need to do more with our gas infrastructure and modernization of the grid. And likely, we'll need further capital investment for renewables. None of this is attributable to the update in the 2008 energy law. These investments will be required with or without a change to that law.
In the past, we reminded you that we've been able to reduce our costs where most of our peers add cost. Our track record is evidence of our ability to be more productive for our customers and our plans for the future continue this. They are based on good business decisions that have already been made that permit ongoing legacy cost reductions, productivity gains as the workforce turns over, the shift from coal to gas generation, the introduction of smart meters and the elimination of waste. As we improve customer quality to better work processes, we'll save on overtime cost and temporary workers by simply doing it right the first time.
For example, nearly 1/3 of the time when we roll trucks on a job, something goes wrong. The right parts are on the truck or other parties who need to be on site aren't always on time. We're aggressively pursuing these opportunities to improve quality for our customers.
For 2014 and 2015, we reduced our costs by 4%, and by 2018 expect to have reduced our costs by at least 10%. While our model is successful with our cost reductions, it helps equally add sales growth. Our team believes that our sales growth will be about 2% this year and in the future, but we plan conservatively. For the purposes of executing our model, we're assuming growth of 1%.
We put all of this together and end up with the attractive business model for our customers, with their level of service and affordability improves every year and the same model permits us to deliver 6% to 8% earnings growth beginning in 2017. It's a reaffirmation of our confidence in our ability to deliver earnings per share and dividend growth at a level that you have come to expect.
Now, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Patti. Let's look at the business for 2015, 2016 and beyond. As you can see here, in 2015, our earnings grew by $0.12 or 20% on a weather-normalized basis. We achieved these consistent results despite the fact that December was the warmest on reco
componenttext:
Thanks, Patti. Let's look at the business for 2015, 2016 and beyond. As you can see here, in 2015, our earnings grew by $0.12 or 20% on a weather-normalized basis. We achieved these consistent results despite the fact that December was the warmest on record, exceeding by 10% the previous record in 1923. For December, Michigan was 37% warmer than normal.
As we mentioned last week, we offset the mild weather and a couple of year-end storms by achieving a tax settlement in Michigan, putting off some donations to our foundation and other improvements. With a mild weather bills were substantially lower than expected, which is helpful to our customers, but it also results in lower uncollectible accounts. So weather was not normal, dragging down profits. Our commitment to manage the work was normal. No excuses from us. We're pleased to have continued great progress for our customers, and once again delivered on 7% growth for our owners.
We achieved all of our financial targets for 2015. These included strong capital investment; healthy balance sheet ratios; dramatic customer price decreases; robust operating cash flow growth; top end of guidance EPS growth; and as announced last week, another substantial increase in our dividend.
For 2016, we're pleased to have raised our guidance to reflect 5% to 7% growth on top of high end 2015 results, which were at the top end of guidance for 2015. We continue to build success upon success, no recess here. While our electric and gas rate cases primarily reflect capital investment, they also permit us to flow through productivity improvements to our customers. This is one of the elements of our model that make high-end earnings growth sustainable. It's also noteworthy that 3 quarters of the rate change impact already has either been authorized or self implemented. And let's not forget the Ferrari -- excuse me, as Patti would say the Tesla in the garage. After all, the Tesla does 0 to 60 in 2.8 seconds, that's faster than the Ferrari Spider.
At DIG, we have long-term energy contracts locked in providing stable results. And with a large portion of capacity available, we continue to have room for upside. Here's our sensitivity slide that we provide each quarter to assist with assessing our prospects. There's not a lot of news, there's seldom is. You can see that with reasonable planning assumptions and with robust risk mitigation, the probability of large variances from our plan are minimized. And while we look forward to the 2008 energy law update, our plan does not reflect any of the upside associated with it.
Our cash flow and earnings growth are driven by our capital investment program. With our recent announcement, increasing capital investment by $1.5 billion to $17 billion over the next 10 years, earnings and cash flow growth will accelerate. Starting in 2017, we are lifting EPS growth guidance to 6% to 8%, bracketing historic growth at 7%. The higher investment kicks in for '17, and we have more O&M reinvestment to accomplish yet this year.
We still have opportunities in excess of $3 billion to add to our plan in the future. For the last 12 years, our gross operating cash flow has been growing by more than $100 million each year. Since 2004, it has increased from $353 million a year to $1.9 billion. Over the next 5 years, it should grow about $800 million to $2.7 billion, cash is king. 
Our net operating cash flow also grows by $0.5 billion. This reflects capital investment recovery, aggressive working capital management and honestly, a little help from Uncle Sam. New bonus depreciation is welcomed, funding part of our increased capital investment and preserving NOLs for future shelter. Amazingly, I have to admit -- amazingly, we may go over 7 years instead of 5, with no need for dilutive-block equity.
While the benefit of bonus depreciation is about 1/3 of our CapEx lift of $1.5 billion, it's half of the rate base increases for the 2016 to 2020 period. With the lift, billing CapEx in behind the Jackson plant purchase, which was accelerated to December 2015 from '16, and our incremental pension contribution rate base rises $1.2 billion, one half of which is funded by bonus depreciation.
This results in an upside to earnings of $0.02 or 1% a year and that starts in 2017.
Here is our new report card. We anticipate another good year of 2016 and an even stronger year in 2017. With no big debts and robust risk mitigation, our model serves our customers and you well. New companies are able to deliver top end earnings growth, while substantially improving value and service for customers.
Value for customers is what has made our plan so sustainable. Here is how we do it. Reasonable cost reductions of 2% to 3%, and service of sales growth at 1%, and other tools that avoid dilution worth another 2% allow us to self-fund 5 points to 6 points of earnings per share growth. Customer base rate increases can be at or below the level of inflation. This very same model that self funds investments for our customers also allows us to self-fund a large portion of our capital needs. The model has worked for a decade. It's our plan for the next 5 years. And that's making it attractive for investors and customers and consequently, sustainable.
John, Patti and I will be visiting Boston and New York next week, and we look forward to answering your questions about these plans. So until then, Steve would you please open the lines to take some questions today.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Dan Eggers with Crédit Suisse.

componenttext: Well, I guess, we've been waiting and debating this -- the growth rate increase for a number of years, so it finally came. What drove you guys in the board to go ahead and make the decision to officially raise the growth rate now versus waiting for legislation, or just kind of following the old playbook of beating every year without raising the growth rate?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, you've been pushing us the hardest for the longest period. I remember saying uncle, in meetings with you. So I'll turn this over to John.
componenttext: Dan, you've been pushing us the hardest for the longest period. I remember saying uncle, in meetings with you. So I'll turn this over to John.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh god, good setup, thank you. Really, what we needed to do is invest the capital. I mean, this is what we talked about, I think, in the last call when we announced Patti's succession plan. At the end of the day is -- we can't wait for the lot to be done
componenttext: Oh god, good setup, thank you. Really, what we needed to do is invest the capital. I mean, this is what we talked about, I think, in the last call when we announced Patti's succession plan. At the end of the day is -- we can't wait for the lot to be done for us to make investment for our customers. And that was clear as we're moving forward. So as we increase the amount, bonus depreciation obviously took a little bit of that way, but it certainly allowed us to continue to grow at even a higher rate than we had before, but also keep our customer rates at or below the rate of inflation. And that's something that we finally decided to do. And as Patti mentioned in her presentation, we also have increased the operating costs, particularly, in the O&M area, that we're seeing the results that our customers want from service and quality. And that's really what we're going after. So now is the time, and obviously with our performance, we think bracketing it between 6% to 8% is the right approach going forward. Go ahead, Patti.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with our operating plan, we have increased confidence in our ability to control cost and make those capital investments, many of them which helped enable those cost reductions that protect our customers from any kind of rate spikes. So we feel very go
componenttext: And with our operating plan, we have increased confidence in our ability to control cost and make those capital investments, many of them which helped enable those cost reductions that protect our customers from any kind of rate spikes. So we feel very good about the total combined effort to achieve 6% to 8%.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, you're kind of in the spirit of keeping the rate -- the inflation below the rate of inflation, legislation presuming it gets done and you have another layer of CapEx that needs to be spent. Does that provide incremental investment opport
componenttext: And then I guess, you're kind of in the spirit of keeping the rate -- the inflation below the rate of inflation, legislation presuming it gets done and you have another layer of CapEx that needs to be spent. Does that provide incremental investment opportunities, or do you think that just resequences how you're going to spend this expanded capital budget?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, as Tom pointed out in his slides, there are opportunities of $3 billion on top of what we are already talking about. So -- but part of that has to come out of not only the law, but I think what's going to come out of that regardless of the la
componenttext: Yes. I mean, as Tom pointed out in his slides, there are opportunities of $3 billion on top of what we are already talking about. So -- but part of that has to come out of not only the law, but I think what's going to come out of that regardless of the law is what happens with Michigan's response to the Clean Power Plan. I mean, that really is going to drive what we do as far as meeting that plan, and those opportunities aren't in there. And as Tom mentioned in his presentation 2, we've got some PPAs that are going to expiring over the next 10 years or within the next 10 years that we need to look at too and see how we're going to replace those.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add one thing. Patti mentioned just a minute ago, the robust nature of the model and the cost reductions that come out of some of the investment. Don't forget of the $3 billion opportunity in CapEx we just talked about. It could be the $2 billio
componenttext: I'll just add one thing. Patti mentioned just a minute ago, the robust nature of the model and the cost reductions that come out of some of the investment. Don't forget of the $3 billion opportunity in CapEx we just talked about. It could be the $2 billion is what John just said, related to these PPAs. We can replace our PPAs cheaper than the PPAs. We can build plants cheaper than what the PPAs are today. So therefore, the model really works, if and when those come in. We still keep our base rate growth down, and we still can grow a little further.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I think what's most important in all this discussion, we continued to do what we say we're going to do. Consistent, predictable, regardless of what the guidance is, we tend to hit it. We have hit it every single year on top of actual results, whi
componenttext: And then I think what's most important in all this discussion, we continued to do what we say we're going to do. Consistent, predictable, regardless of what the guidance is, we tend to hit it. We have hit it every single year on top of actual results, which I think separates us from some others.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ali Agha with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ali Agha with SunTrust.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I look at the data correctly, I believe, weather-normalized electric sales were down, 0.7% in '15? Can you just walk through what caused that? Was that a surprising development? And what gives the confidence that it will be up 1% in '16?
componenttext: If I look at the data correctly, I believe, weather-normalized electric sales were down, 0.7% in '15? Can you just walk through what caused that? Was that a surprising development? And what gives the confidence that it will be up 1% in '16?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. And you can see that on what we call 11 and 12 of our data, and it comes out with a press release. The sales were down and residentials flat, commercials off a little bit, as you can see there, but industrials off a little bit. Recall this,
componenttext: Good question. And you can see that on what we call 11 and 12 of our data, and it comes out with a press release. The sales were down and residentials flat, commercials off a little bit, as you can see there, but industrials off a little bit. Recall this, we actually can't name the customer here, but we do have a customer who has spent most of the year getting a supply issue taken care of. And so they have actually dampened our sales through the year. They're not a big margin, so it's not a big issue. They are starting to turn up already. And so their restoration is just getting back to where they used to be, and I suspect they're going to do better. We'll kind of offset the negative, with a plus this year, but here's the important part. I would tell you -- our internal data tells us that we're going to grow more than what we've shown you today. So where we show you 1% and then 4% on the industrial side, our internal data gives us higher numbers. We just don't believe in going out there with something that we can't deliver on. So we put in more conservative numbers. Here's what's going to drive the uptick. I think, by the way, residential and commercial will still be a little uneven, but I'll just call it flat. The industrial side is coming around because we're seeing new companies hooking up new facilities, new businesses coming into the state and our existing businesses doing better. So for example, we got a brake maker, high-end brake maker, who's going to add 24 megawatts. And I mean, they're building the building and doing the work right now, so that's coming out. We see one of our automotive folks actually putting in new paint facilities and running more extended periods of time. That's another big chunk of megawatts coming in that wasn't there before. We see just a variety of people, particularly, on the food side, housing side, plastic and rubber sector and paper and paper product sector that are all giving us precise information about upticks. So we see some good news and we're happy for that. But we'll tell you, 1% growth, we think will be quite good. It suits our model.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Second question, what happens to the model, if anything -- if we do come back into a period of rising gas prices, which we used to have, but obviously haven't had for last several years. Does that impact your model and your planning in anyway?
componenttext: Understood. Second question, what happens to the model, if anything -- if we do come back into a period of rising gas prices, which we used to have, but obviously haven't had for last several years. Does that impact your model and your planning in anyway?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I would just tell you that these prices are phenomenal. And even if they did rise, and I admit if you look at it from this moment to the next moment a year from now say they did rise, sure, that's an increase, but people are looking at absolute bills,
componenttext: No, I would just tell you that these prices are phenomenal. And even if they did rise, and I admit if you look at it from this moment to the next moment a year from now say they did rise, sure, that's an increase, but people are looking at absolute bills, writing checks. And when they look at where they were, even if we had a substantial rise and they look at where they were just a few years ago, way better situation. They compare gas for whether it's home heating or industrial or electric -- they compare that even with higher prices to alternatives. It is pretty attractive. So we don't see that as a big issue, but I'll tell you again, if you saw the detail of our 5-year plans, you'd see that we had gas prices rising quite a bit. And even inside of that, our model still delivers what we tell you about with being able to keep base rates low, bills low if we can and also grow the business. So for us, we don't see an immediate concern.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just add to that. Ali, one thing about the gas business just to remind everybody, we've got a substantial gas business here, the fourth largest in the country. We've got the largest utility storage field in the country. So at the end of the day whe
componenttext: Let me just add to that. Ali, one thing about the gas business just to remind everybody, we've got a substantial gas business here, the fourth largest in the country. We've got the largest utility storage field in the country. So at the end of the day when gas prices rise, we've had over 300 billion cubic feet of stored gas, both base and working gas, that we can draw out which really keeps us competitive in a rising market. It tends to work the other way in a declining market, actually because the gas in the storage fields tends to be a little bit higher priced than the market. So it does give us a competitive advantage, makes us -- allows us to use our transmission system fully that we're buying gas all through the year, which really helps our customers.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Last question, again, great model, great track record. As you look out the next 5, 10 years, what's your biggest worry? What could potentially go wrong here?
componenttext: Understood. Last question, again, great model, great track record. As you look out the next 5, 10 years, what's your biggest worry? What could potentially go wrong here?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I like what we have. I mean, Patti is sitting here next to me. I feel pretty good about the next 5 years because our plan is unique, and we can see clearly for the 5 years, and the sensitivities that you talk about, we've planned for conservatively. So I
componenttext: I like what we have. I mean, Patti is sitting here next to me. I feel pretty good about the next 5 years because our plan is unique, and we can see clearly for the 5 years, and the sensitivities that you talk about, we've planned for conservatively. So I feel good about that. I actually think the opportunities we have and as Patti's talked about here, with the growth rate and some of the other things we're talking about are better than we've had in the past. And I'll turn it over to you, obviously, it's you're 5 years.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that we are optimistic, and we -- to sustain the kind of performance that we have become known for, it does require endurance. It requires innovation and we have that. And so we are prepared. We have a good eye on what our opportunities a
componenttext: Yes. I would say that we are optimistic, and we -- to sustain the kind of performance that we have become known for, it does require endurance. It requires innovation and we have that. And so we are prepared. We have a good eye on what our opportunities are to continue to make the model work. And so we are -- I would say, very optimistic about our future look here in the next 5 to 10 years.

So when you look at the energy line, you can see it's only 25% available. We contracted most of that.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the bilateral markets do a lot to tell you where you really are right now. Our sense is the energy markets got to some pretty good levels that we liked. So over the last couple of years, we locked in some long-term contracts. On the capacity markets
componenttext: Well, the bilateral markets do a lot to tell you where you really are right now. Our sense is the energy markets got to some pretty good levels that we liked. So over the last couple of years, we locked in some long-term contracts. On the capacity markets, we still see there's going to be some movement up and down. And we see in the ups there will be opportunity. You may recall from the past, we are not trying to wait for a peak and miss it. We're just layering in these capacity contracts as we get to a little bit better levels. So we were doing it in $1 and then $2 and $3, and we've done some recently in $3-plus zone, but we think there's still going to be some opportunities. We like having DIG available as a backup if it had to bid into our utility, but we also like the opportunity that when those markets rise a little bit, because people see a shortfall in Zone 7. We can service that market and that's the upside of the $20 million and $40 million that shows on the slide.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, it looks like -- I will use what the commission has. The latest update is we're about at the capacity level, we're about 500-megawatt short for Zone 7 for this year, but based on 22,000 megawatts, that's in the noise. So really, I think the outlook
componenttext: Paul, it looks like -- I will use what the commission has. The latest update is we're about at the capacity level, we're about 500-megawatt short for Zone 7 for this year, but based on 22,000 megawatts, that's in the noise. So really, I think the outlook if you're thinking about the future, let's look at '17. I mean, as you know, we're closing 7 plants in April of this year. There's some other activity that may occur based on the Clean Power Plan. So let's see what happens in '17, but right now Michigan should be good for this year. I don't think -- see that as a problem. But we're right about that line right now. And also, there's not a lot of new plants being built. So really it's using the excess capacity up.

componenttext: The one thing that I will add. I know you're pulling our leg a little bit on that. But remember what we had said for a long time, we might get up to 6% to 8%, because we really think that is the very high end of the best performers who can do it year-in and year-out. We think when you try to become something you are not, so you try to get performance that's better than a utility. It's only a matter of time before the model breaks. That's why we believe so passionately in the model. We could give you 9% and 10%, but our customers would feel it. So that's not very sustainable. So sorry my $0.02

componenttext: First, quick question, a little bit of a follow-up actually. Let's talk about what's in the garage there again, if you will? I want to know -- the Tesla, let's say, what is the long-term assumption here? So clearly, we have a potential short situation in the near or medium term, you're raising your long-term expectations, do you -- how do you just oppose the higher growth rate with the price trajectory in the long term here for MISO capacity? And I suppose that's implicitly asking where do you see prices going in the 5- to 10-year range?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's interesting, you tied the Tesla slide, which is not the utility to the utility story. And what I would tell you we see our earnings growth and 90-plus percent of our business out of the utility in that 6% to 8% range. And so we feel very good about
componenttext: That's interesting, you tied the Tesla slide, which is not the utility to the utility story. And what I would tell you we see our earnings growth and 90-plus percent of our business out of the utility in that 6% to 8% range. And so we feel very good about that. Now when you talk about the small business and enterprises that's outside of the utility, that's really the dead piece that you're referring to here. And all we're saying is we got a nice steady pattern of profit contribution from that group and this plan. But it is a nice upside opportunity because our view, and we might be wrong but our view is that we'll see capacity prices reach points, where there will be a little higher than this $3 zone that we're in today. The $3 to $4 zone. And we'll be able to take advantage of that and help people. So we see that as an upside that's not in our plan. We think that when we don't know something and we can't count on it, we just don't build it into our plan. We're pretty old-fashioned that way.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I'll see it my way, because I know you're asking it a little bit different. We really do believe in the 6% to 8% growth, and we believe that there are opportunities to do better than that. We may have chances to power right back into our business for our customers as you've seen us do for some time because new things happen. And if there are things we can do for our customers that makes either their prices better or their service better, we're going to go for it and still let you have the 6% to 8%. So I know Julien, you don't want to hear this, but we don't see a plan, where you would expect to see our growth above 6% to 8%. And if that's not good news, that's just the way we think.

componenttext: So I think part of the dividend increase, we've been very clear. We expect the dividend increase to grow with the growth of the company. So when we talk about outsized or larger, it's larger than what most in the industry increase, but as far as a payout ratio, it's very -- it's right at the level that we want to be it. So at the end of the day I expect the future dividend increase to grow with our 6% to 8% guidance in '17 or 5% to 6% guidance in '16.
