headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, quick question, a little bit of a follow-up actually. Let's talk about what's in the garage there again, if you will? I want to know -- the Tesla, let's say, what is the long-term assumption here? So clearly, we have a potential short situation in
componenttext: First, quick question, a little bit of a follow-up actually. Let's talk about what's in the garage there again, if you will? I want to know -- the Tesla, let's say, what is the long-term assumption here? So clearly, we have a potential short situation in the near or medium term, you're raising your long-term expectations, do you -- how do you juxtapose the higher growth rate with the price trajectory in the long term here for MISO capacity? And I suppose that's implicitly asking where do you see prices going in the 5- to 10-year range?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's interesting, you tied the Tesla slide, which is not the utility to the utility story. And what I would tell you we see our earnings growth and 90-plus percent of our business out of the utility in that 6% to 8% range. And so we feel very good about
componenttext: That's interesting, you tied the Tesla slide, which is not the utility to the utility story. And what I would tell you we see our earnings growth and 90-plus percent of our business out of the utility in that 6% to 8% range. And so we feel very good about that. Now when you talk about the small business and enterprises that's outside of the utility, that's really the dead piece that you're referring to here. And all we're saying is we got a nice steady pattern of profit contribution from that group and this plan. But it is a nice upside opportunity because our view, and we might be wrong but our view is that we'll see capacity prices reach points, where there will be a little higher than this $3 zone that we're in today. The $3 to $4 zone. And we'll be able to take advantage of that and help people. So we see that as an upside that's not in our plan. We think that when we don't know something and we can't count on it, we just don't build it into our plan. We're pretty old-fashioned that way.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So said otherwise, you're not banking on any improvement in the 6% to 8% -- if prices were to stay in this $3 range that is your assumption, just said differently?
componenttext: So said otherwise, you're not banking on any improvement in the 6% to 8% -- if prices were to stay in this $3 range that is your assumption, just said differently?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll say it my way, because I know you're asking it a little bit different. We really do believe in the 6% to 8% growth, and we believe that there are opportunities to do better than that. We may have chances to power right back into our business for
componenttext: Yes, I'll say it my way, because I know you're asking it a little bit different. We really do believe in the 6% to 8% growth, and we believe that there are opportunities to do better than that. We may have chances to power right back into our business for our customers as you've seen us do for some time because new things happen. And if there are things we can do for our customers that makes either their prices better or their service better, we're going to go for it and still let you have the 6% to 8%. So I know Julien, you don't want to hear this, but we don't see a plan, where you would expect to see our growth above 6% to 8%. And if that's not good news, that's just the way we think.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think part of the dividend increase, we've been very clear. We expect the dividend increase to grow with the growth of the company. So when we talk about outsized or larger, it's larger than what most in the industry increase, but as far as a payout
componenttext: So I think part of the dividend increase, we've been very clear. We expect the dividend increase to grow with the growth of the company. So when we talk about outsized or larger, it's larger than what most in the industry increase, but as far as a payout ratio, it's very -- it's right at the level that we want to be it. So at the end of the day I expect the future dividend increase to grow with our 6% to 8% guidance in '17 or 5% to 6% guidance in '16.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the CMS Energy 2016 First Quarter Results and Outlook Call. The earnings news release issued earlier today and the presentation used in this webcast are available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations sec
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the CMS Energy 2016 First Quarter Results and Outlook Call. The earnings news release issued earlier today and the presentation used in this webcast are available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
Just a reminder, there will be a rebroadcast of this conference call today, beginning at 12 p.m. Eastern Time, running through May 5. This presentation is also being webcast and is available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. DV Rao, Vice President and Treasurer, Financial Planning and Investor Relations.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. With me are John Russell, President and Chief Executive Officer; Patti Poppe, Senior Vice President of Distribution Operations, Engineering and Transmission and incoming CEO; and Tom Webb, Execut
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. With me are John Russell, President and Chief Executive Officer; Patti Poppe, Senior Vice President of Distribution Operations, Engineering and Transmission and incoming CEO; and Tom Webb, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings for more information regarding the risks and other factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially. This presentation also includes non-GAAP  measures. Reconciliations of these measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the Appendix and also posted on our website.
Now, let me turn the call over to John.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, DV, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on our first quarter earnings call. I'll begin the presentation with a review of our first quarter results and operating performance before turning the call over to Patti to discuss our capital
componenttext:
Thanks, DV, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on our first quarter earnings call. I'll begin the presentation with a review of our first quarter results and operating performance before turning the call over to Patti to discuss our capital investment plan and cost reduction initiatives. Then Tom will provide the financial results and outlook and we'll close with Q&A.
First quarter earnings were $0.59 per share, down $0.14 from a year ago, weather was the primary factor. The mild weather that began last October continued through March, resulting in a second warmest winter on record. On a weather normalized basis, first quarter earnings were up $0.12 or 20% compared to last year. And as you would expect, we have already taken steps to mitigate the unfavorable weather impacts. Patti and Tom will talk more of your plans latter.
But today, we are our full year earnings guidance of $1.99 to $2.2 a share. Earlier this month, we retired 7 coal plans, totaling 950 megawatts, bringing our capacity mix to less than 25% coal. Our regular and routine rate case strategy remains on track. Last week, the commission approved a gas rate case settlement for $40 million, using the previously approved return on equity when required. We filed and electric rate case the 1st of March for $225 million and plan to implement later this year.
We continue to operate with the constructive energy law, the framework allows for fair and timely regulatory treatment. If the law is updated, we see this as being incrementally positive to our customers.
With the recent coal plant closures, we are proud of the fact that we have reduced the most coal capacity of any investor-owned utility. The gas for our Jackson Generating Station and new windfarms have been added to our portfolio, making our capacity mix more sustainable.
Additionally, we continue to offer energy efficiency programs, which reduced demand at 1% annually. This strategy puts us in a good position to meet future carbon reduction requirements, and as I always enjoy saying, the air is cleaner today in Michigan that has ever been in my lifetime.
On a regulatory track record is among the best in the nation. Over the last 5 years, we have filed gas and electric cases to recover capital investments and pass along O&M savings to our customers. This has been the foundation of our sustainable business model for the past decade.
In some years, our O&M reductions fully offset our capital investment needs, and we were able to avoid 3 rate cases. During this time, the ROE has remained unchanged at a competitive 10.3% for gas and electric. The latest gas rate case was the fourth consecutive one that we have settled dating back to 2011.
The current energy law in Michigan is working well, it allows us to execute our business plan, while making needed infrastructure investments and providing energy savings programs to our customers. However, the law still requires that 99.98% of our customers subsidized about 300 large customers. This is simply not fair. We believe that updates the law would be beneficial to our customers by securing reliable capacity and reducing rates. This is an opportunity for our legislatures and we will work with them on constructive updates.
Whether or not the legislators decide to act, we will continue our plan with the current law in place and move to 6% to 8% earnings growth for 2017 and beyond. There are many external factors that can affect our operational and financial results, but we work through everything and work with everyone. We remain focused on delivering the consistent and predictable results that you have come to expect. It has been an honor and privilege for me to lead the team that is delivered results over the past 6 years. I believe the company is better today than it has ever been, both financially and operationally, with a very bright future.
Now let me turn the call over to Patti, who will lead the execution of our model.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and especially, thank you for your leadership and your contribution to our company over your entire career. CMS Energy is definitely better and when you took the helm of our CEO and President, in fact, if I do my math correctly, I think, we'
componenttext: Thanks, John, and especially, thank you for your leadership and your contribution to our company over your entire career. CMS Energy is definitely better and when you took the helm of our CEO and President, in fact, if I do my math correctly, I think, we're talking about $8 billion better, under your watch, through positive that you walk the talk and follow your model to leave it better than you found it.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the reasons that we're optimistic that we'll can do to get better is our capital investment and our gas and electric utility. As we've said, over the next 10 years, we plan to invest $17 billion and that is a 60% increase over what we invested in t
componenttext:
One of the reasons that we're optimistic that we'll can do to get better is our capital investment and our gas and electric utility. As we've said, over the next 10 years, we plan to invest $17 billion and that is a 60% increase over what we invested in the prior years. Each project is that well, in fact, add customer value.
These customer value -- the customer value takes the form of customer service, improved -- reducing costs, enhancing our productivity, enabling cleaner energy, all of these improvements drive customer value. And in fact, many of the investments provide improvements in several of these categories.
For example, our customers benefit with fewer and shorter outages when we make our investments in our electric infrastructure that not only improves the customer experience, but reduces costs. Our customers benefit when they can move into their college, apartment, hookup to Consumers Energy the service online, on their mobile phone, never speak to a customer service rep and because of our smart energy and smart meter investments, we can remotely turn on their power. No truck required.
This not only improve the customer experience end to end, but fundamentally reduces the structural cost to do so. Our smart energy program is a great example, of a major capital investments that have ongoing benefits to customers on both the service and the cost side of the equation.
Other cost savings are driven by proactively investing in replacement of legacy gas service lines, so that we can prevent an unscheduled maintenance expense and customer disruption. Our gas compression upgrades use of fuel technology, allow for a more productive workforce and less unplanned expense. And with our ongoing transition from coal to gas and our increasing renewable energy investments, we demonstrate to our customers everyday that CMS Energy is, in fact, a great steward of our great state.
As you all know, this model has been working for a long time, it's delivered results for more than a decade and the approach continues now and into years to come with our extensive inventory of our self-funded organic capital investment projects, and really importantly, offset by abundant cost reduction opportunities.
And a diverse economy, you can see why it works, especially, with the continuing focus on our cross reductions, which I'll talk a little more about. you Know, we've been a leader in this area and each year we come up with new and innovative ways to deliver both savings to our customers, from investors that means we're able to create CapEx headroom and at the same time, fulfilled our internal commitment to keep those base are increases below inflation.
Cost reductions have been and continue to be an important part of our self-funded model, but we don't cherry pick this when you put all the numbers together. We take the bad with a good we don't adjust for inflation and things are well control and in the past several years our focus has delivered an average of 3% savings, and we have a plan well plan -- a well articulate plan to execute another 6% in savings over the next 2 years. I'll give you a little more detail on that.
In fact, I'm often asked that if he continued performance and this is how I see it. And when we look at a total O&M cost per customer we look great and -- among the best of all utilities, but when I dig deep and look into our distribution numbers, we can see that you still only in the third  So for both electric and gas distribution there is more room. And in fact, when they make up a third of our total O&M expense we know this is more opportunity there.
For example, we will -- when we go to a job site, only 70% of the time to be built a job per plan. That means that the wrong material was probably ordered, maybe too much, maybe too low. The right equipment may not be available and right make up may cause a delay. We can eliminate that ways and reduce expense by improving our first time quality and More broadly, we're embarking on a companywide improvement effort and each day real savings are materializing. This approach to our first time quality is a value creation mechanism that enables for us continued cost, reductions and at the same time, deliver our 6% to 8% EPS growth in 2017 and beyond, and at the same time, improve our customers experience and keep it affordable.
As I look around, I see opportunities toward the whole company. We haven't established track record on which we can build new and innovative ways to serve our customers at a lower structural cost and on both realistic and enthusiast about what the future holds for CMS.
Now let me turn the call over to Tom.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Patti, and thank you, everybody, for joining us every day on this very busy day. This is my 54th quarterly CMS earnings call, and as usual, no surprises.Our first quarter earnings are down $0.14 reflecting the cold winter last year and mild weat
componenttext:
Thanks, Patti, and thank you, everybody, for joining us every day on this very busy day. This is my 54th quarterly CMS earnings call, and as usual, no surprises.
Our first quarter earnings are down $0.14 reflecting the cold winter last year and mild weather this year. On a weather normalized basis 2016 earnings are up $0.12 or 20%. Weather normalized all operations, the gas utility, electric utility, enterprises interest and other were -- at or favorable to plan in 2015.
You can see the unfavorable comparison of 2016 to 2015 weather on this waterfall chart. Our operations are performing well better than plan, which offsets the weather in the first quarter of 2016. For the 9 months to go, if we experienced just normal weather will be $0.16 ahead of 2015 and that's the run milder conditions existed. Cost reductions are ready underway keep us right on track for 5% to 7% earnings per share growth.
Here is how the earnings per share forecast curve looked last year. We were able to reinvest $38 million into the business for our customers because cost reductions were better than planned and the 2014, '15 winter was cold. Towards the end of the year, the warm winter of 2015, '16 began, but we fully offset it delivering our 13th year of consistent EPS growth at 7%.
This slide adds our forecast of EPS growth for 2016. As mentioned, adverse weather in 2016 has been offset fully. The winter of 2015, '16 was the second warmest ever not even this, however, than our ability to deliver 5% to 7% growth without any customer compromises.
For example, we were able to enhance cost reductions including normal changes that come with mild weather, like lower uncollectible accounts, because customer base actually lowered. In late December, with 2015 cash flow better-than-expected, we made a pension contribution improving profits 2 pennies for 2016.
While the improvement programs similar to the capitalization of pole top hardening work a $0.03 better than planned. We also adopted a new approach for applying the interest rates to determine the interest cost on pension and healthcare obligations, this was worth a nickel.
This new approach was permitted by a favorable SEC interpretation of a proposal by AT&T just last year. The use of this PBO weighted application of interest rates reduces volatility and it improved earnings in 2016. Each year of pension obligation is actually discounted by its yield curve rate as they would have its own pension plan.
In stead of the conventional approach of rating all years by the same average interest rate as shown in orange on the slide, this new approach shown in green reduces the cost of interest in the near and years partly offset by higher costs in far out years. For a defined benefits program like ours, one that we closed about 10 years ago, the advantageous and our volatility has reduced. We're big fans of lower volatility at CMS.
This new approach produced in earnings improvement of the nickel a share in 2016, which helped to offset the abnormal weather. Here's a look at our EPS curves for the last several years. You can see every year is different, but we have always delivered 7% EPS growth by managing the business on behalf of customers and investors. Over the last 3 years, we have reinvested to $38 million in 2 customer improvements, half from favorable weather and half from higher than planned cost savings. Yes, that's worth repeating. We invested in O&M $238 million for our customers and we delivered 7% earnings growth.
Most of you are aware that recent 1 year MISO capacity of for Zone 7. Capacity cost were $2.19 a kilowatt month, which is about 1/4 of the cost of building new capacity. This, however, had little direct impact on our business at the, I'm sorry, the tesla in the garage that Dearborn Industrial Generation facility.
Most of our 2017 contracts are bilateral and were in place before the auction. New contracts completed by March added $15 million to our profitability for 2017 increasing profits to $35 million, a nice lift towards the 6% to 8% growth guidance for 2017.
We still have upside opportunity including 25% of big energy and 50% to 90% of capacity depending on the year, still available for 2018 and beyond. The MISO capacity auction results were close to being $1 or more higher incentivizing bilateral customers to pay a bit more to reduce their risk. This could add $20 million to $40 million of profit in the future.
As you can see on our sensitivity table that we provide each quarter, risk are not large than mitigation to minimize our exposure continues to be robust. Just last month, relating to notches in a parent rating a notch. Moody's put the utility in apparent on a positive outlook. It's nice to see the agencies recognizing our balance sheet and business model strength.
For the year, we're at or above all of our financial targets. From investments to cash flow to customer prices, the dividend and EPS growth, we expect strong performance again this year.
Our business model continues to work well, self funding most of our capital investments for customers, leading the rate increases at our below the level of inflation. This model is focused on decisions that benefit customers and investors. This permits performance that is sustainable continuing our track record of consistent high end results or nearly 15 years, look forward to continuing this track record together, and John it's a pleasure to have done 6 years of this calls for the best CEO in the business.

componenttext:
First of all, congratulations John. Thanks so much. It's pleasure to work with you.
I just had a quick question within the legislation having been introduced into the Senate. Is there read through that maybe some common ground has been found with the Chamber of Commerce and the schools?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The fact that as we reduced it is positive. I think, that there's been discussions going on with the schools and the chamber about supporting this bill or the ones from the house. The bills that came out -- everybody knows their bills introduced set the g
componenttext:
The fact that as we reduced it is positive. I think, that there's been discussions going on with the schools and the chamber about supporting this bill or the ones from the house. The bills that came out -- everybody knows their bills introduced set the groundwork the bills were deduced. Two of them bills. In the Senate, energy committee yesterday and they were focused on the things we talked about before. The centered at --- had to do with retail open access. 10% cap stays, but the suppliers need to have firm forward capacity in Michigan. And any further new ROA customer would have to pay a capacity charge. So we think that even though it would be nice to get to a fully regulated entity, that seems to be reasonable.
Part of that was the integrated resource plan, which is good for preapproved generating cost or generation of cost. And regulatory, there are some changes there, which is good for I think, everybody, including us. The chamber needs to decide what they want to do with these. At the end, as I said earlier, it's an unfair system in Michigan that we have today where 300 customers of our 1.8 million customers benefit and are 99.98% of our customers pay 3% to 4% more on their cost to subsidize these other customers.
So I think what in the right thing, let's get the Senate built out, get the Senate and try to get as much a somewhat we possibly can. As for the schools are concerned, the same thing, few schools take choice, most of them don't, at the end of the day the pay more. The chamber, few of their customers take choice, most of them don't, they pay more. So I hope both of those organizations will be on the right side of this.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There is a great point about those that I'd want to continue it, and again, if I were subsidized I want to continue too. So that has been the battle. The issue is that it's just not fair to our customers and as we shut down 7 coal plants and there wa
componenttext: Yes. There is a great point about those that I'd want to continue it, and again, if I were subsidized I want to continue too. So that has been the battle. The issue is that it's just not fair to our customers and as we shut down 7 coal plants and there was another plant closed in Michigan, you see the results of the MISO auction that Tom talked about. beginning to show that we have may have capacity to tightening up. And if we do that means that new supply along with energy efficiency needs to be combined and move forward. Well -- In the most capital intensive industry in the world with the most part of the product in the world it's hard to make investments unless you have certainty and that's with the law I think it's time to provide. And I think that's what Senator is liable to answer to do going. Can I handicapped with is going to get through I know the Senate to confident about that. My opinion is it gets more of a challenge in the house, and that something that you seen before. So I don't really want to handicap it right now, if figured I think it would be an upside, but I do want to emphasize that we are not counting on any law changes to our 10-year plan, not our 5-year plan, but our 10-year plan. And as Patti has taken over, she is growing the business, to 6% to 8%, her and Tom, I think, that's is great. And none of it is depending on the law changes. So if the law changed its good for our customer and there maybe some upside to us, but that really is the intent that we're focused on is that what's fair for our customers, and I think some of the issues many of you be talking in the next 2 minutes in Ohio is a good indication of what should not happen here in Michigan.

componenttext: That's a great question. So the $0.05 is deposited impact from the change in how we calculate the interest on pension and healthcare cost. So I don't want that to sound it's just the first quarter thing, that's the full year impact, you still have other impacts or things like remember the discount rate still moves up and down, so that could change things next year give you a little good news, little bit of bad news, but $0.05 for that change is the full year effect. In the future, we'll remeasure each year in January, but what we think we've done is taken volatility out of that particular calculation, but you still could have I'm go to the big side a penny maybe 2 up or down, but less than what we've looked at in the past. Did that help?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our sales in the quarter were flat, but here is what interesting. If you look at the weather normalized sales, we actually are showing in our reports, which you can look at attached the release that residential and commercial down about 2%. I tell you
componenttext:
So our sales in the quarter were flat, but here is what interesting. If you look at the weather normalized sales, we actually are showing in our reports, which you can look at attached the release that residential and commercial down about 2%. I tell you -- I actually don't believe that, I don't think the rather adjusted year period correctly. Last year, the first quarter was very cold and we said, our residential and commercial sales were like 2% up. Now we're comparing to that what was really mild and we're saying 2% down. What we saw in the second quarter last year with that sort of reverse, it just said, oops your weather calculations aren't too good. I think we'll published that this. I hate this date, but I just don't believe that fall of an residential and commercial will continue, but I do believe if you look forward and think of those as kind of flat. We're not seeing great growth there.
If the industrial side interesting. Our industrial side was actually up 5%. And if you take 1 customer out, we were actually up 9% in the first quarter. There is a lot of good news in their the food business was up about 4%, plastics sector up about 4%, transportation up about 7%, packaging was up about 10% and here is something that I really like to see. Several of our companies in the building sector was up a lot, cement side was about 17%. So there is a lot going on where we can see the uplift through industrial, but keep in mind, we are conservative beast, we're still telling you that for the years we go out, we're looking for about 1% growth, overall, but I'll admit the bulk of that will be on the industrial side.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. Let me take those in a couple of pieces. First of all, we gave you a little bit of good news showing that for 2017, the layer --  and that's a good way to think about how this capacity contracts are being put in. A little bit more good news layered
componenttext:
Good. Let me take those in a couple of pieces. First of all, we gave you a little bit of good news showing that for 2017, the layer --  and that's a good way to think about how this capacity contracts are being put in. A little bit more good news layered in, a little bit more good news layered in with contracts. We are not trying to grab what we think is a peak or rush to anything. We'll miss the pick, we'll miss the trough. But the laying strategy should give us some good news. So I'd say the $35 million numbers are pretty good for 2017, you know from the chart we showed you, we still have about 25% of our energy and our capacity available, so there is some more uptake that could come from that.
Now with the future. As you look odd further in time and we have anywhere starting in 2018 out through time and your time, 50% to 90% of capacity and still 25% of energy because we got some nice long-term contracts on energy. I don't want to predict how much of the $20 million to $40 million upside will happen except to say because we layered in -- I don't think you should expect the full $40 million, that would be getting to replacement cost. But on the other hand, I'm not so negative as to say it will only grow by another $20 million. So I think what you try to do is give you the zone somewhere in between there that we honestly believe will be achieved depending on the prices and bilateral demand and what we're able to do as a business.

componenttextpreview: Nice and complicated what they are. What we as a going forward that MISO is going to change of decision options, they're going to change into multi-auctions and I wouldn't even battle the guess what that really mean. But what we can look at it just occurr
componenttext:
Nice and complicated what they are. What we as a going forward that MISO is going to change of decision options, they're going to change into multi-auctions and I wouldn't even battle the guess what that really mean. But what we can look at it just occurred that $2.19 per kilowatt a month, if you laid the bits down right along the demand line and you all densities it's all public record. You can see that it stays pretty close in their. So with a modest change of what was happening in the market on the demand side, that could have easily been $3-plus. So what that does to people that are interested in reducing the volatility they come to businesses like the Tesla, whatever we want to call -- they will come there, looking for ways to take out volatility and pay a little higher price than the auctions, 1-year auctions, at least, to protect themselves from an exposure.
So I do see a little upside from that based on that. The bigger picture is it's telling you a little bit about what John talked to. The capacity situation for Zone 7 is just not all that sold. So as changes occurred in demand on the supply side I think that you see a market that could threaten up quite a bit and it's very hard to predict, but a year from now, I just suspect it will be probably be a tighter market on capacity. Now that's just a personal opinion, so I'll leave it that.

componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the CMS Energy 2016 First Quarter Results and Outlook Call. The earnings news release issued earlier today and the presentation used in this webcast are available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
Just a reminder, there will be a rebroadcast of this conference call today, beginning at 12 p.m. Eastern Time, running through May 5. This presentation is also being webcast and is available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. DV Rao, Vice President and Treasurer, Financial Planning and Investor Relations.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. With me are John Russell, President and Chief Executive Officer; Patti Poppe, Senior Vice President of Distribution Operations, Engineering and Transmission and incoming CEO; and Tom Webb, Execut
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. With me are John Russell, President and Chief Executive Officer; Patti Poppe, Senior Vice President of Distribution Operations, Engineering and Transmission and incoming CEO; and Tom Webb, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings for more information regarding the risks and other factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially. This presentation also includes non-GAAP measures. Reconciliations of these measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the Appendix and also posted on our website.
Now, let me turn the call over to John.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, DV, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on our first quarter earnings call. I'll begin the presentation with a review of our first quarter results and operating performance before turning the call over to Patti to discuss our capital
componenttext:
Thanks, DV, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on our first quarter earnings call. I'll begin the presentation with a review of our first quarter results and operating performance before turning the call over to Patti to discuss our capital investment plan and cost reduction initiatives. Then Tom will provide the financial results and outlook, and we'll close with Q&A.
First quarter earnings were $0.59 per share, down $0.14 from a year ago, weather was the primary factor. The mild weather that began last October continued through March, resulting in a second warmest winter on record. On a weather normalized basis, first quarter earnings were up $0.12 or 20% compared to last year. And as you would expect, we have already taken steps to mitigate the unfavorable weather impacts. Patti and Tom will talk more about our plans later. But today, we are reaffirming our full year earnings guidance of $1.99 to $2.02 a share. 
Earlier this month, we retired 7 coal plants, totaling 950 megawatts, bringing our capacity mix to less than 25% coal. Our regular and routine rate case strategy remains on track. Last week, the commission approved a gas rate case settlement for $40 million, using the previously approved return on equity when required. We filed an electric rate case the 1st of March for $225 million and plan to self-implement later this year. We continue to operate with the constructive energy law, the framework allows for fair and timely regulatory treatment. If the law is updated, we see this as being incrementally positive to our customers.
With the recent coal plant closures, we are proud of the fact that we have reduced the most coal capacity of any investor-owned utility. The gas-fired Jackson Generating Station and new wind farms have been added to our portfolio, making our capacity mix more sustainable. Additionally, we continue to offer energy efficiency programs, which reduced demand at 1% annually. This strategy puts us in a good position to meet future carbon reduction requirements, and as I always enjoy saying, the air is cleaner today in Michigan than it's ever been in my lifetime.
On a regulatory -- our regulatory track record is among the best in the nation. Over the last 5 years, we have filed gas and electric cases to recover capital investments and pass along O&M savings to our customers. This has been the foundation of our sustainable business model for the past decade. In some years, our O&M reductions fully offset our capital investment needs, and we are able -- and we were able to avoid 3 rate cases. During this time, the ROE has remained unchanged at a competitive 10.3% for gas and electric. The latest gas rate case was the fourth consecutive one that we have settled, dating back to 2011.
The current energy law in Michigan is working well, it allows us to execute our business plan while making needed infrastructure investments and providing energy savings programs to our customers. However, the law still requires that 99.98% of our customers subsidize about 300 large customers. This is simply not fair. We believe that updates to the law would be beneficial to our customers by securing reliable capacity and reducing rates. This is an opportunity for our legislators, and we will work with them on constructive updates.  Whether or not the legislators decide to act, we will continue our plan with the current law in place and move to 6% to 8% earnings growth for 2017 and beyond. 
There are many external factors that can affect our operational and financial results, but we work through everything and work with everyone. We remain focused on delivering the consistent and predictable results that you have come to expect. It has been an honor and a privilege for me to lead the team that has delivered these results over the past 6 years. I believe the company is better today than it has ever been, both financially and operationally, with a very bright future.
Now let me turn the call over to Patti, who will lead the execution of our model.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and especially thank you for your leadership and your contribution to our company over your entire career. CMS Energy is definitely better than when you took the helm as our CEO and President, in fact, if I do my math correctly, I think, we'
componenttext: Thanks, John, and especially thank you for your leadership and your contribution to our company over your entire career. CMS Energy is definitely better than when you took the helm as our CEO and President, in fact, if I do my math correctly, I think, we're talking about $8 billion better under your watch through positive that you walk the talk and follow your model to leave it better than you found it.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the reasons that we're all optimistic that it will continue to get better is our capital investment in our gas and electric utility. As we've said, over the next 10 years, we plan to invest $17 billion and that is a 60% increase over what we invest
componenttext:
One of the reasons that we're all optimistic that it will continue to get better is our capital investment in our gas and electric utility. As we've said, over the next 10 years, we plan to invest $17 billion and that is a 60% increase over what we invested in the prior years. Each project is screened to ensure they will, in fact, add customer value. These customer value takes the -- the customer value takes the form of customer service, improved -- reducing costs, enhancing our productivity, enabling cleaner energy. All of these improvements drive customer value, and in fact, many of the investments provide improvements in several of these categories.
For example, our customers benefit with fewer and shorter outages when we make our investments in our electric infrastructure, that not only improves the customer experience, but reduces costs. Our customers benefit when they can move into their college, apartment, hook up to Consumers Energy service online, on their mobile phone, never speak to a customer service rep, and because of our smart energy and smart meter investments, we can remotely turn on their power. No truck role required. This not only improves the customer experience end to end, but fundamentally reduces the structural cost to do so. Our Smart Energy program is a great example of a major capital investment that has ongoing benefits to customers on both the service and the cost side of the equation.
Other cost savings are driven by proactively investing in replacement of legacy gas service lines, so that we can prevent an unscheduled maintenance expense and customer disruption. Our gas compression upgrades and the use of fuel technology allow for a more productive workforce and less unplanned expense. And with our ongoing transition from coal to gas and our increasing renewable energy investments, we demonstrate to our customers every day that CMS Energy is, in fact, a great steward of our Great Lakes state.
Now you all know, this model has been working for a long time. It's delivered results for more than a decade, and the approach continues now and into years to come with our extensive inventory of our self-funded organic capital investment projects, and really importantly, offset by abundant cost reduction opportunities. In a diverse economy, you can see why it works, especially with the continued focus on our cross reductions, which I'll talk a little bit more about. You know, we've been a leader in this area, and each year we come up with new and innovative ways to deliver both savings to our customers. For investors that means we're able to create CapEx headroom and at the same time, fulfill our internal commitment to keep those base rate increases below inflation.
Cost reductions have been and continued to be an important part of our self-funded model, but we don't cherry-pick this when we put all the numbers together. We take the bad with the good. We don't adjust for inflation or things out of our control. And in the past several years, our focus has delivered an average of 3% savings, and we have a plan -- a well plan -- a well-articulated plan to execute another 6% in savings over the next 2 years. I'll give you a little more detail on that. In fact, I'm often asked if we can continue our performance, and this is how I see it. When we look at our total O&M cost per customer, we look great, in fact, we're among the best of all utilities. But when I dig deep and look into our distribution numbers, we can see that we're still only in the third quartile. So for both electric and gas distribution there's more room, and in fact, when they make up 1/3 of our total O&M expense, we know there is more opportunity there.
For example, we will -- when we go to a job site, only 70% of the time do we built that job per plan. That means that the wrong material was probably ordered, maybe too much, maybe too little. The right equipment may not be available and the right crew makeup may cause a delay. We can eliminate that waste and reduce expense by improving our first-time quality and standardization. More broadly, we're embarking on a company-wide improvement effort and each day real savings are materializing. This approach to our first-time quality is a value creation mechanism that enables for us continued cost reductions and at the same time, deliver our 6% to 8% EPS growth in 2017 and beyond and at the same time, improve our customers' experience and keep it affordable. As I look around, I see opportunities throughout the whole company. We haven't established track record on which we can build new and innovative ways to serve our customers at a lower structural cost. And I'm both realistic and enthusiastic about what the future holds for CMS.
Now let me turn the call over to Tom.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Patti, and thank you, everybody, for joining us today on this very busy day. This is my 54th quarterly CMS earnings call, and as usual, no surprises. Our first quarter earnings are down $0.14, reflecting the cold winter last year and mild weathe
componenttext:
Thanks, Patti, and thank you, everybody, for joining us today on this very busy day. This is my 54th quarterly CMS earnings call, and as usual, no surprises. 
Our first quarter earnings are down $0.14, reflecting the cold winter last year and mild weather this year. On a weather-normalized basis, 2016 earnings are up $0.12 or 20%. Weather-normalized all operations, the gas utility, electric utility, enterprises, interest and other were at or all favorable to plan in 2015. 
You can see the unfavorable comparison of 2016 to 2015 weather on this waterfall chart. Our operations are performing well better than plan, which offsets the weather in the first quarter of 2016. For the 9 months to go, if we experience just normal weather will be $0.16, ahead of 2015, that's when milder conditions existed. Cost reductions already underway keep us right on track for 5% to 7% earnings per share growth.
Here is how the earnings per share forecast curve looked last year. We were able to reinvest $38 million into the business for our customers because cost reductions were better than planned and the 2014-'15 winter was cold. Toward the end of the year the warm winter of 2015-'16 began, but we fully offset it delivering our 13th year of consistent EPS growth at 7%.
This slide adds our forecast of EPS growth for 2016. As mentioned, adverse weather in 2016 has been offset fully. The winter of 2015-'16 was the second warmest ever. Not even this, however, dense our ability to deliver 5% to 7% growth without any customer compromises. For example, we were able to enhance cost reductions including normal changes that come with mild weather, like lower uncollectible accounts, because customer bills are actually lower. In late December, with 2015 cash flow better than expected, we made a pension contribution improving profits $0.02 for 2016.  While the improvement program similar to the capitalization of pole top hardening work are $0.03 better than planned. 
We also adopted a new approach for applying the interest rates to determine the interest cost on pension and healthcare obligations. This was worth $5. This new approach was permitted by a favorable SEC interpretation of a proposal by AT&T just last year. The use of this PBO-weighted application of interest rates reduces volatility and it improved earnings in 2016. Each year of pension obligation is actually discounted by its yield curve rate as though it had its own pension plan. Instead of the conventional approach of weighting all years by the same average interest rate, as shown in orange on the slide, this new approach, shown in green, reduces the cost of interest in the near-end years, partly offset by higher cost in far-out years. For a defined benefits program like ours, one that we closed about 10 years ago, the advantageous height in our volatility has reduced. We're big fans of lower volatility at CMS. And this new approach produced an earnings improvement of $5 a share in 2016, which helped to offset the abnormal weather. 
Here's a look at our EPS curves for the last several years. You can see every year is different, but we have always delivered 7% EPS growth by managing the business on behalf of customers and investors. Over the last 3 years, we reinvested $238 million into customer improvements, half from favorable weather and half from higher than planned cost savings. Yes, that's worth repeating. We reinvested in O&M $238 million for our customers, and we delivered 7% earnings growth.
Most of you are aware the recent 1-year MISO capacity auction for Zone 7. Capacity costs were $2.19 a kilowatt-month, which is about 1/4 of the cost of building new capacity. This, however, had little direct impact on our business at the -- I'm sorry, the Tesla in the garage, the Dearborn Industrial Generation facility. Most of our 2017 contracts are bilateral and were in place before the auction. New contracts completed by March added $15 million to our profitability for 2017 increasing big profits to $35 million, a nice lift towards the 6% to 8% growth guidance for 2017. We still have upside opportunity, including 25% of big energy and 50% to 90% of capacity, depending on the year, still available for 2018 and beyond. The MISO capacity auction results were close to being $1 or more higher, incentivizing bilateral customers to pay a bit more to reduce their risk. This could add $20 million to $40 million of profit in the future.
As you can see on our sensitivity table that we provide each quarter, risks are not large and mitigation to minimize our exposure continues to be robust. Just last month, Fitch upgraded the utility rating 2 notches and the parent rating a notch. Moody's put the utility and the parent on a positive outlook. It's nice to see the agencies recognizing our balance sheet and business model strength.
For the year, we're at or above all of our financial targets. From investment to cash flow to customer prices, the dividend and EPS growth, we expect strong performance again this year. 
Our business model continues to work well, self-funding most of our capital investment for customers, leading rate increases at or below the level of inflation. This model is focused on decisions that benefit customers and investors. This permits performance that is sustainable, continuing our track record of consistent high-end results for nearly 15 years. Patti, I look forward to continuing this track record together. And John, it's a pleasure to have done 6 years of these calls with the best CEO in the business.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a quick question. With the legislation having been introduced into the Senate, is there any read-through that maybe some common ground has been found with the Chamber of Commerce and the schools?
componenttext: I just had a quick question. With the legislation having been introduced into the Senate, is there any read-through that maybe some common ground has been found with the Chamber of Commerce and the schools?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The fact that it's been introduced, I think, is a positive. I think that there's been discussions going on with the schools and the chamber about supporting this bill or the ones from the house. The bills that came out -- everybody know there are bills in
componenttext: The fact that it's been introduced, I think, is a positive. I think that there's been discussions going on with the schools and the chamber about supporting this bill or the ones from the house. The bills that came out -- everybody know there are bills introduced. I just set the groundwork. The bills were introduced, two of them substitute bills in the Senate, Energy Committee, yesterday, and they were focused on the things we talked about before. Senator Nesbitt had to do with retail open access. 10% cap stays, but the suppliers need to have firm forward capacity in Michigan. And any further new ROA customer would have to pay a capacity charge. So we think that even though it'd be nice to get to a fully regulated entity, that seems to be reasonable. Part of that was the integrated resource plan, which is good for pre-approved generating cost or generational cost, and regulatory, there are some changes there, which is good for, I think, everybody, including us. The chamber needs to decide what they want to do with these. At the end of the day, as I said earlier, it's an unfair system in Michigan that we have today where 300 customers, over 1.8 million customers benefit, and 99.98% of our customers pay 3% to 4% more on their cost to subsidize these other customers. So I think what's Senator Nesbitt is doing is the right thing. Let's get the Senate bill out, get it through the Senate and try to get as much support as we possibly can. As far as the schools are concerned, the same thing. Few schools take choice, most of them don't, at the end of the day, they pay more. The chamber, few of their customers take choice, most of them don't, they pay more. So I hope both of those organizations would be on the right side of this.

componenttext: I also just wanted to sort of touch base on the legislation. When you have a bunch of people who are subsidized, often they can be pretty effective in blocking things. And the legislation hasn't been going as quickly as you might have expected earlier, and I'm just wondering any sense about that? I mean, you did sort of address it with Paul Ridzon just now, but I mean, how do you guys feel about its chances of passing, I guess, at this point?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Here is a great point about those that have it want to continue it, and again, if I was subsidized, I'd want to continue too. So that has been the battle. The issue is that it's just not fair to our customers, and as we shut down 7 coal plants and th
componenttext: Yes. Here is a great point about those that have it want to continue it, and again, if I was subsidized, I'd want to continue too. So that has been the battle. The issue is that it's just not fair to our customers, and as we shut down 7 coal plants and there was another plant closed in Michigan, you see the results of the MISO auction that Tom talked about, it's beginning to show that we have may have capacity tightening up. And if we do that means that new supply along with energy efficiency needs to be combined and move forward. Well, in the most capital-intensive industry in the world with the most volatile product in the world, it's hard to make investments unless you have certainty, and that's what the law, I think, is trying to provide. I think that's what Senator Nesbitt's primary view is reliability and certainty going forward. Can a handicap weather is going to get through it or not, I think it will get through the Senate. I'm pretty confident about that. My opinion is it gets more of a challenge in the house, and that's something that we've seen before. So I don't really want to handicap it right now. If we get it, I think it would be an upside. But I do want to emphasize that we are not counting on any law changes to our 10-year plan, not our 5-year plan, but our 10-year plan. And as Patti is taking over, she is growing the business to 6% to 8%, her and Tom, I think, that's great, and none of it is dependent on the law changes. So if the law does change, it's good for our customers and there may be some upside to us, but that really is the intent that we're focused on is that what's fair for our customers. And I think some of the issues that many of you will be talking about in the next few minutes in Ohio is a good indication of what should not happen here in Michigan.

componenttext: That's a great question. So the $0.05 is the positive impact from the change in how we calculate the interest on pension and healthcare cost. So I don't want that to sound like it's just a first quarter thing, that's the full year impact. You still have other impacts or things like -- remember the discount rate, still moves up and down, so that could change things next year to give you a little good news, little bit of bad news. But $0.05 for that change is the full year effect. In the future, we'll remeasure that each year in January. But what we think we've done is taken volatility out of that particular calculation, but you still could have -- I'm going to go to the big side of $0.01, maybe $0.02 up or down, but less than what we've looked at in the past. Did that help?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our sales in the quarter were flat, but here is what's interesting. If you look at the weather normalized sales, we actually are showing in our reports, which you can look at attached to the release, that residential and commercial are down about 2%. I
componenttext: So our sales in the quarter were flat, but here is what's interesting. If you look at the weather normalized sales, we actually are showing in our reports, which you can look at attached to the release, that residential and commercial are down about 2%. I'll tell you, I actually don't believe that. I don't think we weather-adjusted year-to-year correctly. Last year, the first quarter was very cold, and we said our residential and commercial sales were like 2% up. Now we're comparing to that what was really mild, and we're saying 2% down. What we saw in the second quarter last year was that sort of reversed. It just said, oops, your weather calculations aren't too good. I think we'll probably see that in this year. So I hate to dismiss data, but I just don't believe that fall off in residential and commercial will continue. But I do believe, if you look forward, think of those as kind of flat. We're not seeing great growth there. If the industrial side -- it's interesting. Our industrial side was actually up 5%. And if you take one customer out, we were actually up 9% in the first quarter. So there's a lot of good news in there. The food business was up about 4%, the plastic sector up about 4%, transportation up about 7%, packaging was up about 10%, and here is something that I really like to see. Several of our companies in the building sector were up a lot. Cement side was about 17%. So there is a lot going on where we can see the uplift through industrial, but keep in mind, we are a conservative beast. We're still telling you that for the years we go out, we're looking for about 1% growth overall, but I'll admit the bulk of that will be on the industrial side.

And obviously, we've seen some improvement in that pricing, and obviously, it doesn't moved the needle too much. And then also your existing contracts and ultimately, the earnings profile of our multi-year period. I'll leave it there.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. Let me take those in a couple of pieces. First of all, we gave you little bit of good news, showing that for 2017 the layering in, and that's a good way to think about how these capacity contracts are being put in. A little bit more good news
componenttext: Okay, good. Let me take those in a couple of pieces. First of all, we gave you little bit of good news, showing that for 2017 the layering in, and that's a good way to think about how these capacity contracts are being put in. A little bit more good news layered in, a little bit more good news layered in with contracts. We are not trying to grab what we think is a peak or rush to anything. We'll miss the peak, we'll miss the trough. But the layering in strategy should give us some good news. So I'd say the $35 million number is pretty good for 2017. You know from the chart we showed you, we still have about 25% of our energy and our capacity available, so there is some more uptick that could come from that. Now go to the future. As you look out further in time, we have anywhere starting in 2018 out through time, near time, 50% to 90% of capacity and still 25% of energy because we got some nice long-term contracts in place on energy. I don't want to predict how much of the $20 million to $40 million upside will happen except to say because we layer in -- I don't think you should expect the full $40 million, that would be getting to replacement cost. But on the other hand, I'm not so negative as to say it will only grow by another $20 million. So I think what we've tried to do is give you the zone, somewhere in between there, that we honestly believe will be achieved depending on the prices and a bilateral demand and what we're able to do as a business.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And to be explicit about your going-forward expectations and where these auction results go out, what do you think of these reforms in terms of impacts on pricing?
componenttext: Got it. And to be explicit about your going-forward expectations and where these auction results go out, what do you think of these reforms in terms of impacts on pricing?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice and complicated is what they are. So what we're going to see going forward is MISO is going to be changing the seasonal auctions, they're going to be changed into multi-year auctions. And I wouldn't even fathom the guess about what that will really m
componenttext: Nice and complicated is what they are. So what we're going to see going forward is MISO is going to be changing the seasonal auctions, they're going to be changed into multi-year auctions. And I wouldn't even fathom the guess about what that will really mean. But what we can look at is the data that just occurred, that $2.19 per kilowatt-month. If you laid the bids down right along the demand line, and you all can see this. It's all public record. You can see that it stays pretty close in there. So with a modest change of what was happening in the market on the demand side, that could have easily been $3-plus. So what that does to people that are interested in reducing their volatility, they come to businesses like the Tesla, the Ferrari or DIG, whatever we want to call it, they will come there looking for ways to take out volatility and pay a little higher price than the auctions, those 1-year auctions, at least, to protect themselves from an exposure. So I do see a little upside from that based on that. The bigger picture is, it's telling you a little bit about what John talked to. The capacity situation for Zone 7 is just not all that solid. So as changes occur in demand or in the supply side, I think that you see a market that could tighten up quite a bit, and it's very hard to predict, but a year from now, I just suspect it will probably be a tighter market on capacity. Now that's just a personal opinion, so I'll leave it that.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
