componenttext: It is, but Julien, also keep in mind. The part you don't want to hear, as we do more and more this year, we'll put that surplus cost improvement to work for more reliability and all that good stuff. But what it does for us is, gives us headroom. So it allows us to fit in more investment.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Absolutely. Second question kind of a legislative angle. Can you comment more broadly, if you're unable to get, call it comprehensive legislation. Have you guys thought to doing something a little bit specific or tactical? Just be curious, if there
componenttext: Right. Absolutely. Second question kind of a legislative angle. Can you comment more broadly, if you're unable to get, call it comprehensive legislation. Have you guys thought to doing something a little bit specific or tactical? Just be curious, if there's potentially a new avenue for something more specific?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say that, first of all, again the changes to the energy policy are not embedded in our plan. But what we do think is important for the state to address is the idea that alternative energy suppliers don't have to demonstrate that they have firm capacit
componenttext: I'd say that, first of all, again the changes to the energy policy are not embedded in our plan. But what we do think is important for the state to address is the idea that alternative energy suppliers don't have to demonstrate that they have firm capacity. And through MISO's recent 3-year forward-looking capacity auction proposals we'll be curious and observing, and we have filed comments that when they make their filing with the FERC in mid-August, we'll have a better indicator of some of the changes that they are recommending will, in fact, be a way to help address that loophole, where people can sell power that they don't actually have. We want to make sure that gets fixed to assure reliability and resource adequacy in Michigan.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ali Agha with SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ali Agha with SunTrust.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, Tom, can you just elaborate a little bit on this tax settlement you referred to? Was that just a Q2 event? Will that have lingering impacts over the course of the year? How should we be thinking about that?
componenttext: First, Tom, can you just elaborate a little bit on this tax settlement you referred to? Was that just a Q2 event? Will that have lingering impacts over the course of the year? How should we be thinking about that?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the tax settlement was around use taxes. And it's something we've been working on for, gosh! it's almost a decade and a half. And the way I would ask you to think about that, that's a nice benefit that we're glad to have this year, because it was worth
componenttext: So the tax settlement was around use taxes. And it's something we've been working on for, gosh! it's almost a decade and a half. And the way I would ask you to think about that, that's a nice benefit that we're glad to have this year, because it was worth $0.03 in this quarter. But it's a onetime thing. There's a little bit of a benefit going forward, but it's not big enough that you should get excited about it, right? So what we do is, we're looking at that, that's a nice offset to the onetime bad weather that we had in the first quarter. So kind of lines up and gives you a good quality of earnings. So we're glad to have it. It's been a long time coming. And we're delighted that the Michigan Treasury is happy and so are we.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The second question. You refereed to the low interest rates and the implications of that. Just thinking of that from a another vantage point. One of the positives in Michigan from a regulatory perspective is that your authorized ROEs are above industry av
componenttext: The second question. You refereed to the low interest rates and the implications of that. Just thinking of that from a another vantage point. One of the positives in Michigan from a regulatory perspective is that your authorized ROEs are above industry average and they've been very consistent. Just wondering in this persistent low interest rate environment, are you getting any sense that, there may be pressure on authorized ROEs? Or is your sense that the regulators still remain very comfortable with where they are at?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't want to speak for the regulators, but I would say this is that when you look at the authorized ROEs, including riders and things that people have, we're really not that far out of line with the better performing utilities around the country.
componenttext: Well, I don't want to speak for the regulators, but I would say this is that when you look at the authorized ROEs, including riders and things that people have, we're really not that far out of line with the better performing utilities around the country. So I don't think it's that special of a thing. And then I'd also agree that as interest rates come down, it puts pressure on where those number should be. You can see by our request in both of our rate cases that we think that there's something between where we're asking and where the staff often would be, that there's kind of a middle point in there that's around that 10.3%. So we're hopeful that they see the usefulness and importance of that and the competitiveness of that level and that could sustain.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then thirdly, Patti, the goal to get to the top quartile, you said another $30 million gets you there. How long do you think it takes you to get to that level? And then related to that, Tom I guess, the cost savings you laid out for '16, '17, ov
componenttext: Okay. And then thirdly, Patti, the goal to get to the top quartile, you said another $30 million gets you there. How long do you think it takes you to get to that level? And then related to that, Tom I guess, the cost savings you laid out for '16, '17, over a long period of time, how much more can you think you can dig out of the system to continue that very impressive cost reduction program?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Ali, I'll answer the first part of the question. As we build our plan for run rate of our distribution costs and distribution cost per customer, I would -- we see a path to mid to late 2018 gets us to the top quartile. And then additional savings co
componenttext: Well, Ali, I'll answer the first part of the question. As we build our plan for run rate of our distribution costs and distribution cost per customer, I would -- we see a path to mid to late 2018 gets us to the top quartile. And then additional savings come from a sustained commitment to continuous improvement and waste elimination. And so that's the -- I'd say, that's the time horizon we'd be looking for first quartile competitiveness.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just then add to that. Because I know it's a good question that people do ask us and we ask ourselves. So if you look at that slide that talks about the O&M cost performance, you'll see a line in there called attrition, for an example. And that lin
componenttext: Let me just then add to that. Because I know it's a good question that people do ask us and we ask ourselves. So if you look at that slide that talks about the O&M cost performance, you'll see a line in there called attrition, for an example. And that line is nothing but, we lose about 400-or-so people each year through retirements and the like, and when we bring somebody into replace that with our new programs for defined contributions to the defined benefit and different healthcare for new employees. We save a good chunk of money, about $40,000 with each turnover. So that times the 400 gets into $16 million a year, and that's 1.6% of our O&M right there all by itself. That sustains for a good many years, because we still have a large population of older guys like me. So there'll be more people that take advantage of that over time. And then, I would say, beyond smart meters and productivity and VSP programs and all that, what Patti has described that we're proud to talk about is the Consumers Energy way, it provides a lot of opportunity that she's shown some specifics on. But it provides opportunities in everything we do. It cuts into the finance organization, it cuts into the back office. It isn't just the operating piece out front. We can be a lot better at what we do smartly, not painfully.

componenttext: Just -- are you aware of anything going on behind the scenes in Lansing, so that we can hit the ground running in the lame duck session?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we know that there will be conversations in the short window before the election when the Senate comes back into session. We don't expect that the house would take it up before that. But if the Senate can come to some conclusions before the election
componenttext: Well, we know that there will be conversations in the short window before the election when the Senate comes back into session. We don't expect that the house would take it up before that. But if the Senate can come to some conclusions before the elections then in that lame duck it's possible, but I would say, that we don't think it's likely.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then what about into '17?
componenttext: And then what about into '17?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So then there are elections -- implications of the elections this fall, particularly, in the house. There's a lot of seats up for grab. There are some people who are predicting that the house could shift from Republican to Democrat. That would be a big ch
componenttext: So then there are elections -- implications of the elections this fall, particularly, in the house. There's a lot of seats up for grab. There are some people who are predicting that the house could shift from Republican to Democrat. That would be a big change. Term limits are a real challenge in Michigan, because it requires then that all new legislators have to be briefed on a variety of subjects, including this complicated one. So I doubt that they would hit the ground running, but certainly, I would expect that we will be back at it, come the start of the year.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'd just add to that, as Patti said earlier, remember nothing of this new law whatever it might be, is in our plan, and we are pretty happy with the 2008 energy law. It gives us so many wonderful things that we can do. So it's got to be good meaningfu
componenttext: And I'd just add to that, as Patti said earlier, remember nothing of this new law whatever it might be, is in our plan, and we are pretty happy with the 2008 energy law. It gives us so many wonderful things that we can do. So it's got to be good meaningful change when it occurs.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Weinstein [ph] with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Weinstein [ph] with Crédit Suisse.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- when you were talking about competitive suppliers and the requirement to buy capacity for their customers. In the absence of those requirements though, I'm wondering what is the energy and capacity shortage or availability situation in the state lo
componenttext: The -- when you were talking about competitive suppliers and the requirement to buy capacity for their customers. In the absence of those requirements though, I'm wondering what is the energy and capacity shortage or availability situation in the state look like over time? I mean, at what point in the future do you see a critical shortage of capacity in Michigan and in Zone 7, Zone 4?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so Zone 7, we see -- and it was recently published. A 300-megawatt shortfall in 2017 is the forecast that eats into the reserve margin pretty significantly. And by 2021, up to doubling of that, 600 megawatts, with just the publicly announced plant c
componenttext: Well, so Zone 7, we see -- and it was recently published. A 300-megawatt shortfall in 2017 is the forecast that eats into the reserve margin pretty significantly. And by 2021, up to doubling of that, 600 megawatts, with just the publicly announced plant closures. As you know, DTE announced several closures recently. So that definitely is in the forecast. What's not in that forecast is any other early retirements of other units. So again, we do think that it's a critical issue that needs to be addressed. And we need to assure that the people who are selling power in Michigan have that power that they can actually provide the power they've sold. And so it does highlight the issue that exists in Zone 7 with this hybrid market.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, in the interim, if there's a shortage, how do you meet that shortage?
componenttext: I guess, in the interim, if there's a shortage, how do you meet that shortage?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we are certainly able to cover the load of our customers. Where we have adequate supply and reserve margin to serve the 90% of the load in our service territory. And so we're -- we are covered. The question will be how do the alternative providers c
componenttext: Well, we are certainly able to cover the load of our customers. Where we have adequate supply and reserve margin to serve the 90% of the load in our service territory. And so we're -- we are covered. The question will be how do the alternative providers cover? Now on a hot day, when we have to deploy, there is a whole emergency set of procedures that MISO invokes across the entire region, if there are constraints on any given day. And so there's a whole procedure to manage that, obviously, all the peakers come on, and everyone is required to ramp up everything they've got, and then we dial download purposefully as the programs with those customers allow demand response, et cetera. So that's obviously an important part of the mix as well.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's on a couple of IPPs left, and we're one of them, called DIG. So it puts us in a good spot to back up the utility, so that we do what's needed there. And it also puts the state in a good spot, having that bit of an insurance policy. But we all agre
componenttext: There's on a couple of IPPs left, and we're one of them, called DIG. So it puts us in a good spot to back up the utility, so that we do what's needed there. And it also puts the state in a good spot, having that bit of an insurance policy. But we all agree. It's something that needs to be addressed, so we have more certainty going forward.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would it be accurate to say that on Slide 18, when you talk about the $4.50 to $7.50 possibilities going forward capacity, is that the high end of that range would be a shortage condition where there is no other solution? DIG just -- is the solution to se
componenttext: Would it be accurate to say that on Slide 18, when you talk about the $4.50 to $7.50 possibilities going forward capacity, is that the high end of that range would be a shortage condition where there is no other solution? DIG just -- is the solution to serving the region?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd say what we see in the market as we do bilateral market sales. The upside opportunity is between $4.50 and $7.50. You might sell a little bit at $7.50, but I wouldn't think of us selling what's left there. That would be probably a more aggressive
componenttext: Yes. I'd say what we see in the market as we do bilateral market sales. The upside opportunity is between $4.50 and $7.50. You might sell a little bit at $7.50, but I wouldn't think of us selling what's left there. That would be probably a more aggressive assumption than realistic. So somewhere in between there, is what could happen in the market and that would be good opportunity for us. You'll note that we've sold a lot of our energy. So that just make sense to do long-term contracts out of DIG. But we've held a lot of our capacity available, one for the situation and two, for insurance for our utility to make sure that we've got backup.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if MISO does a 3-year forward-looking auction, it does give more visibility and these bilateral agreements than become more attractive depending on what that auction foretells. So I think a 3-year forward-looking capacity auction would be a good enabl
componenttext: And if MISO does a 3-year forward-looking auction, it does give more visibility and these bilateral agreements than become more attractive depending on what that auction foretells. So I think a 3-year forward-looking capacity auction would be a good enabler to what Tom is describing.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Arnold with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Arnold with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. Sort of you're $0.13 ahead on weather so far, you alluded to the hot and muggy July. Give us a sense of what the through July number might look like? And then as well what are you reinvesting in, currently? What's the best way of deploying
componenttext: Two questions. Sort of you're $0.13 ahead on weather so far, you alluded to the hot and muggy July. Give us a sense of what the through July number might look like? And then as well what are you reinvesting in, currently? What's the best way of deploying those extra dollars in the system? And is there a possibility you kind of you run out of stuff to do?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd answer the last part, no. And then ask everyone, if they look at the slide called the 2016 EPS outlook, which is a little curvy chart. To your point, Jonathan, there's a little box there that shows how we did the recovery. A lot of that's ongoing stuf
componenttext:
I'd answer the last part, no. And then ask everyone, if they look at the slide called the 2016 EPS outlook, which is a little curvy chart. To your point, Jonathan, there's a little box there that shows how we did the recovery. A lot of that's ongoing stuff. And some of that's onetime things, like the use tax. And then you'll see that we show ourselves running up, because we are doing better on our cost reductions than we anticipated. So we are on the upside sort of with opportunities to reinvest more. The weather side that you're asking about, which is in addition to that. If you just took July for what we know for the month so far, there is $0.03, $0.04 of earnings upside associated with that. But I'm always cautious with those kind of numbers because what's August going be like, $0.03, $0.04 up again or down, we don't know. We just plan on normal weather in our projections. So where can we put that money to work. Oh, there's so many opportunities. We can pull some outage work ahead from next year into this year. That helps next year's results and helps our reliability. So we're looking at that. We can do more on the tree trimming side. That's probably the single biggest thing we can do to improve our  reliability. And so there's a place that we can do more work on and above and beyond what we've been authorized to do by the commission.
There's also more esoteric things, like low-cost financing. If these rates continue to stay low, we can take a hard look and we can make these decisions sooner or later, we can go pretty far back into the year and decide let's just take on some more low interest debt and pre-fund some of our future debt. And all that does is it might cost us a little bit for settling this year, there is the investment part, but it will save more money, create more profits, '17 and sometimes forward years. So I could go on, because there's an awful long list. But those are some of the areas that are very practical and they're on our radar screen, and we're looking at them and we're timing them in a way that we think allows us to do the max performance for our customers, and then not miss the earnings growth.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then -- can you just remind us when -- how far out your no equity look currently is?
componenttext: Great. And then -- can you just remind us when -- how far out your no equity look currently is?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we go out to 2021 and 2022. And there is in the appendix of your material, a slide that I would refer folks to, so that you wouldn't miss that. It's our operating cash flow slide. It's got a big yellow arrow flying over showing that we take o
componenttext: Yes. I think we go out to 2021 and 2022. And there is in the appendix of your material, a slide that I would refer folks to, so that you wouldn't miss that. It's our operating cash flow slide. It's got a big yellow arrow flying over showing that we take out about -- or improve our operating cash about $100 million a year. And on the bottom box, you can see our NOLs and credits in the yellow side. And you can see they go out through 2021. So it will be 2021, 2022 before we're looking at needing any block equity. But I caution you again, 10 years running predicting that incorrectly, it could go out further.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Leslie Rich with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Leslie Rich with JPMorgan.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on Slide 13. You have a $0.13 there attributable in part to pension yield curve and enhanced capitalization. Could you just walk through what that is? Why the pension yield curve -- what the yield curve moving down why that's a benefit?
componenttext: A question on Slide 13. You have a $0.13 there attributable in part to pension yield curve and enhanced capitalization. Could you just walk through what that is? Why the pension yield curve -- what the yield curve moving down why that's a benefit?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is that new process that we put in place toward the beginning of this year. Where it is looking at how you do your expenses when you're discounting the pension costs, and what we're now doing is actually discounting, if you will, at the point of
componenttext: Yes. This is that new process that we put in place toward the beginning of this year. Where it is looking at how you do your expenses when you're discounting the pension costs, and what we're now doing is actually discounting, if you will, at the point of each year as opposed to an average of all the years. And by doing that, that actually gives us a better look at how to reflect on our programs. So like our defined benefit pension program, where it's closed. New employees aren't coming into that. So the bulk of our liability is more upfront than it is in the back. So by taking low interest rates in the curve early on, it's cheaper for us. And of course, as you go out in time and the curve rises above the average, it's a little more expensive. But that's a big savings to us. And it should as well as we go into the future years, minimize the amount of volatility we have, when we're looking at discount rates and the pension curve interest rates. And that may be why when I said earlier, the impact of 50 basis points on our pension plan and OPEB is only about $12 million. I know, I've heard that's a bigger number for some companies. But it could be because our program is closed. New employees come into a D.C. program. And then on the enhanced capitalization, all that is, that is just where we really should be capitalizing work we're doing instead of putting it in O&M. That allows our customers to get a better deal, they pay for it later. But that's also a benefit for us as we do that. Because that's less O&M expense, and so that our profits are higher, if you will. So we're just doing a little more of that. One of the examples that you may recall, we've used a few times in our slides is called pole top maintenance. And that's just where we do a little more complete work, complete when there is a storm, replacing a whole pole top, cross arms and the like instead of just doing bits and pieces. By doing the whole work, we get to capitalize it instead of count it as O&M. Are those a couple of good examples for you?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Weisel with Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Weisel with Macquarie.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is a follow-up on DIG. It looks like you sold some more capacity in energy for '17. And yet the outlook for expected income hasn't changed. Does that basically just mean that the prices were in line with your expectations? Or any other movi
componenttext: First question is a follow-up on DIG. It looks like you sold some more capacity in energy for '17. And yet the outlook for expected income hasn't changed. Does that basically just mean that the prices were in line with your expectations? Or any other moving parts there?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No other moving parts whatsoever. Good observation. It showed 25% last time, we're at 0% now. That's around the energy side, and we pretty much -- it's a lot of that light blue bar that you see up there in '17. We had factored that in at the prices th
componenttext: No. No other moving parts whatsoever. Good observation. It showed 25% last time, we're at 0% now. That's around the energy side, and we pretty much -- it's a lot of that light blue bar that you see up there in '17. We had factored that in at the prices that we expected. So there was no big uptick in our numbers from that.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then moving forward, you said you want to keep some -- I forget if it was energy or capacity or both. Do you have a targeted amount of how much you'd want to retain for those future years?
componenttext: Okay. And then moving forward, you said you want to keep some -- I forget if it was energy or capacity or both. Do you have a targeted amount of how much you'd want to retain for those future years?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're at a bit of our sweet spot right now. On energy, we have about 25% available as we go out in the future. Now, we'd be happy to actually market and sell a little bit of that, as the right opportunities come up with long-term contracts. On the 5
componenttext: Well, we're at a bit of our sweet spot right now. On energy, we have about 25% available as we go out in the future. Now, we'd be happy to actually market and sell a little bit of that, as the right opportunities come up with long-term contracts. On the 50% to 90% available, that's already you could tell at a ramp as you go through the years. We wanted to keep that 50% level. One, as an insurance policy for our utility, in case it was needed. And two, because we really do think, economically those prices will be a little bit better and that's what we used to call the layering in capacity contracts. So we're not trying to be greedy. And we are trying to be patient. So we are layering them in as they are little bit better, each time we get a chance. And so if some more come up, if there was another good deal, we might layer in some more. We don't have one right now.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Very helpful. My next question is on the weather-adjusted low growth. Residential has been a little bit volatile recently. I believe it was down about 2% in the first quarter then up 4% this quarter. Any comments on the trends there? You're not rea
componenttext: Great. Very helpful. My next question is on the weather-adjusted low growth. Residential has been a little bit volatile recently. I believe it was down about 2% in the first quarter then up 4% this quarter. Any comments on the trends there? You're not really a story based on load growth, but just curious what you're -- what's driving that -- those moments? And what you're expecting for this year and beyond?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In part, it's our highly skilled ability to do weather adjustments. Maybe we're not the best in the business. So you're right. And to be a little more precise, in the first quarter, our residential sales were down 2.1%. We scratched our heads and we said,
componenttext: In part, it's our highly skilled ability to do weather adjustments. Maybe we're not the best in the business. So you're right. And to be a little more precise, in the first quarter, our residential sales were down 2.1%. We scratched our heads and we said, "It can't be right." It's got to be a weather adjustments when we get more than 1 or 2 standard deviations away from normal. So here we are in the second quarter. Now, we're up 3.8% for residential. Now, often people would cheer and say, "Isn't that great?" and build stories around it. I actually scratch our heads and say, "Isn't that a little bit of the weather adjustment again?" So what I like to do and I hope you'll bear with us is sort of average those 2 together. And what we will tell you that we think is that, if we're in a small growth this year that would be nice. But what we're planning on is a small decline for residential. We may be -- for the full year, we may be a little conservative on that. And on commercial, we say it's going to be flat. And I think, we're realistic on that. And then on industrial, we'll tell you we'll be up 2.5-plus-percent. And I think that's pretty realistic too. Because we did see -- didn't ask about it, but it tick down on the industrial side. And what we saw there was still good strength on food, manufacturing, automotive, chemicals, a whole -- construction, a whole variety of areas, were ticking up nicely as we expecting. But metals did not do well. I think that has to do with the competitive pressure coming out of China. And in addition, we had a couple of our bigger businesses, one on the construction side with insulation, in fact, that just did an acquisition and they're actually relaying out a lot of their production facilities. And I wouldn't even mention it except that it was a 1% decline all by itself. So we may have some oddities on the industrial side in our report for this quarter. We'll see how that plays out. Does that help you?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, very helpful commentary.
componenttext: Yes, very helpful commentary.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the CMS Energy 2016 Third Quarter Results and Outlook Call. The earnings news release issued earlier today and the presentation used in this webcast are available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations sec
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the CMS Energy 2016 Third Quarter Results and Outlook Call. The earnings news release issued earlier today and the presentation used in this webcast are available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section. This call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions].
Just a reminder, there will be a rebroadcast of this conference call today, beginning at 1:00 p.m. Eastern Time, running through November 3. This presentation is also being webcast and is available on CMS Energy's website in the Investor Relations section.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Sri Maddipati, Vice President of Treasury and Investor Relations.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. With me are Patti Poppe, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Webb, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.This presentation contains forward-looking statements, which are subject
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. With me are Patti Poppe, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Webb, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our SEC filings for more information regarding the risks and other factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially. This presentation also includes non-GAAP measures. Reconciliations of these measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the appendix and posted on our website. Now I will turn the call over to Patti

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sri.  Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on our third quarter earnings call. For those of you who have not yet met Sri, he is our new Treasurer and Vice President of IR. Sri has been with CMS for a couple of years, and we are excited to
componenttext:
Thanks, Sri.  Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us on our third quarter earnings call. For those of you who have not yet met Sri, he is our new Treasurer and Vice President of IR. Sri has been with CMS for a couple of years, and we are excited to have him in his new role. I will begin the presentation with an update to earnings and describe our simple, but powerful model. Tom will then provide the detailed financial results and outlook, and we will finish with some Q&A. We're happy to report adjusted earnings [ph] for the first 3 quarters are up $0.22, and we've narrowed our guidance to the high end of our forecasted range of $2 to $2.02 for 6% to 7% over last year's performance. As a reminder, we previously announced our long-term adjusted EPS guidance of 6% to 8%, and we're introducing today specific 2017 earnings guidance of $2.13 to $2.17 a share. It was a strong quarter and that sets us up for a strong finish to 2016. The strong finish will be led by our continued implementation of the Consumers Energy way. We're proud of our consistent financial performance. My coworkers are motivated to serve our families, friends and neighbors. There are many times, however, when those same coworkers, in spite of their best efforts, are unable to serve our customers to our desired standards. Many of our processes are [ph] burdened with waste that goes unchecked and the CE way is simply a lean operations model focused squarely on business results, [indiscernible] customer focus standards, implemented by enabled employees, working within well designed and standard processes and a mindset that every day there is an opportunity for continuous improvement.  Completing our work safely with [ph] high quality, low cost and on time will deliver the same consistent results for customers and investors that we've had for over a decade.
As a result of our efforts, I'm more confident than ever in our ability to deliver our simple, but powerful model. We have debts in our organic capital plan. I've yet to attend a meeting where we have trouble identifying opportunities to invest. We have a long shopping list with lots of investments that improve safety, reliability, affordability and our customers' experience. Nothing new here. We will tackle the structural cost with the [ph] smart investment, good business decision-making and continuous process improvement. We plan conservatively for sales growth, and we don't dilute our earnings with black equity. All of this adds up to sustainable model that enables investment, while keeping our rates affordable. Like I said, our shopping list is long, and we're not making any big bets to fill out the plan. We have a large electric distribution system. It's made up of over 70,000 [ph] miles of conductor, 1,200 substations that all need to be upgraded and maintained, and we have a lot of work to do just to modernize our  grid starting with completing our electric smart meter installations in 2017. We continue to increase our gas investments. I like to remind people that we have a great gas business where smart investments have real return for our customers. We still have to say no to projects because we can't spend more than our customers can afford. Our [ph] generation fleet continues to evolve in small bites. Incremental renewables, capacity upgrades, coal to gas conversions, these are all small bets that add real value and cost savings, cleaner energy and reliability for our customers. And future PPA replacements could even potentially allow for additional investment without affecting customers' bills. The ability to pay is always our limiting factor, which is why we're so focused on sustainable and structural cost reduction. It's not easy to be the leader [indiscernible] on cost reductions year over year over year. However, that is our ambition. 
Let me remind you that many of our previous decisions were structural, permanent and have many years of favorable impact. For example, our conversion to define contribution plans have significantly reduced our long-term liabilities. Each year, as my coworkers retire and replaced by a new workforce, we save about 1.6% of the previous year's O&M before we tackle a single work process improvement with the CE way.  We have a lot more gas pedal and waste elimination that results in real cost savings. Those cost savings then allow us to be focused on making our prices competitive, so that we can continue to be part of the Michigan growth story. We are seeing positive momentum, cooperation and success stories related to our customers' growth and economic development in our service territory. We're bullish on Michigan. The more we improve our business model, the more companies and their employees will choose Michigan as a place to locate or grow their businesses. And the stats don't lie. Michigan is growing faster than the U.S. average, and Grand Rapids, the heart of our electric territory, is growing faster than the Michigan average. We feel great about being part of that success today and into the future. And still we plan conservatively for low growth.
As we continue to maximize customer value with a strong investment portfolio to drive waste out of our operations and [ph] let customer affordability be our throttle, we'll continue to deliver high end and quality earnings growth. Our constructive relationships with our state policymakers, legislators and regulators is based on keeping our promise to perform and to care for our customers and communities. And performance is power. When we perform at best-in-class levels, we can earn the trust and admiration and deliver hometown service for our customers. Day in and day out, you and our customers can count on us. Now I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Patti. Third quarter results at $0.67 were up $0.14 compared with a year ago. Adjusted to exclude the cost of our voluntary separation program, results were $0.70 or up [ph] $0.17. In either case, this is substantially better than our original pla
componenttext:
Thanks, Patti. Third quarter results at $0.67 were up $0.14 compared with a year ago. Adjusted to exclude the cost of our voluntary separation program, results were $0.70 or up [ph] $0.17. In either case, this is substantially better than our original plan, even as it reflects meaningful O&M reinvestment, permitted by cost reductions ahead of plan and the warm, muggy summer. And for the first 9 months, overall, our GAAP earnings were $1.70 a share, up $0.19 from last year. Adjusted for the [ph] VSP cost, results were $1.73, up $0.22 or 23% on a weather-normalized basis. As you can see here again, our performance in the first 9 months is $0.22 better than last year. Adverse weather hurt $0.10. We blew away our 5% to 7% [ph] EPA growth target, growing more than 10%, including the mild winter weather. Improvements included benefit savings, lower uncollectible accounts, coal plant closures, [ph] pole top hardening, higher demand, and productivity at DIG, to name just a few of the areas. Looking ahead into the fourth quarter, if weather is just normal, we'll accomplish a nice uptick of $0.13 compared with 2015. And as you know, we already have a head start on the fourth quarter with cost reductions well ahead of plan. We also have an electric rate case underway and [ph] still implemented at $170 million on September 1. We filed a gas rate case last August, which  will support 2017. We've plenty of room for reinvesting O&M for our customers this year, and we raised our 2016 guidance to the high end of our 5% to 7% range. This has become an investor favorite slide, where we share our projected earnings per share growth for the full year. And this is as the year progresses.
During the first quarter, mild winter weather and abnormal storms reduced earnings per share by $0.13, but in a very short period of time, we were right back on track [ph] for our adjusted earnings growth at 5% to 7%. You can see the improvements that offset the abnormal weather with no impact on customers. We're well ahead of our guidance and as always, are putting the upside to work for customers, improving reliability, [ph] moving ahead work from next year as well as prefunding debt maturities, and we will deliver consistent peer-leading earnings per share growth. We beat guidance and delivered 7% adjusted earnings growth for almost 15 years. Here is a picture of that track record. It shows how we consistently offset bad news and put good news to use for our customers without compromising predictable earnings growth of 7% each and every year. Over the last 3 years, favorable weather and cost reductions in excess of our plan generated room to reinvest $0.25 billion for our customers, $0.25 billion. Half of that came from favorable weather and half from cost productivity better than planned. That's a big number. We put these savings to work in many beneficial ways. So far this year, we're 20% ahead of our plan. Our customers and investors really will benefit.
In addition to our cost performance, our conservative view of sales growth and our ability to avoid diluted equity, we still have other attractive upsides. As you can see in this slide, continued layering [ph] in of energy and capacity sales could enable us to increase our profitability by $20 million to $40 million at our Dearborn Industrial Generation operations. Recent capacity sales have exceeded $4 a kilowatt month. This is a nice insurance policy for our utility, if it needs more capacity and a catalyst for new growth. And to help you with your own assessment of our future performance, here is our standard profit and cash flow sensitivity slide. Recall that impacts from many legislative changes are not in our plan. Interest rate shifts, up or down, largely offset [ph] at our company as changes in debt cost offset changes in discount rates on our pension plans. We believe in no big bets and strong risk mitigation. And here is our report card. For 2016, we're right on course to achieve our plans for capital investment, a high-quality balance sheet, competitive customers prices, a robust dividend payout and strong operating cash flow. We're well ahead of our adjusted earnings per share growth in the 5% to 7% range. Therefore, we raised guidance to the high end. We've introduced specific guidance for 2017 at $2.13 to $2.17, up 6% to 8% from this year. Count on another strong year, our 15th in a row, with high-end predictable earnings, cash flow and dividend growth. This is my [ph] 57th CMS quarterly call in a row. Maybe my voice is wearing out and [indiscernible] has been sharing with you the results of a great team delivering consistent industry-leading earnings per share growth for over 14 years. We intend to continue this next year and for a long time. Our earnings and dividend growth continue at a predictable high pace every year, no matter what's happening in the economy, the weather, politics or succession planning. And I think all of you who have met Patti can certainly attest to that. Thank you for your interest and your support. Patti and I will be delighted to take your questions. So, Tracy, would you be kind enough to open the telephone lines? Thank you.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of [ph] Antoine with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of [ph] Antoine with UBS.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's is Julien. Just a couple of questions. Can you go over a little bit of what the pull-forward opportunities are for the $0.15 you kind of [indiscernible] here. Just as a little bit on the flavor each one of those in terms of what they mean in terms fo
componenttext: It's is Julien. Just a couple of questions. Can you go over a little bit of what the pull-forward opportunities are for the $0.15 you kind of [indiscernible] here. Just as a little bit on the flavor each one of those in terms of what they mean in terms for the timing perspective recognition '17 onwards.  And then I got a follow-up on [ph] some of the policy side.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. So what Julien is talking to, if you all have the slides handy, it was Slide #12, the slide I called an investor favorite, I know it's mine. And it's got that curve in it with the little blue box in it. That blue box in terms of what are some
componenttext: Absolutely. So what Julien is talking to, if you all have the slides handy, it was Slide #12, the slide I called an investor favorite, I know it's mine. And it's got that curve in it with the little blue box in it. That blue box in terms of what are some of the [ph] pull-aheads, what are some of the choices that we have with all this favorable performance from better cost reductions than we'd actually planned, and we had a nice toasty summer here at the end with a nice humidity that we don't always get in lovely Michigan, which helped us a bit. But in that box, you see a few different items. First one is [ph] pull-aheads. Those are traditional things that we do. If we can take work from next year and pull it into this year, it makes the job we have to do next year easier. And so some examples are, there were some small outages that we're able to pull ahead. A little bit of tree trimming are pulled ahead during the course of the year, things that improve reliability, things that help us be a better company for our customers and make our job a little bit easier as we go into 2017. The next item that is listed there is called debt prefunding. I think everybody knows, we're such chickens that we go out and prefund our parent debt at least 2 years in advance to ensure that if there was a nightmare scenario of 2007, 2008 proportions, we wouldn't have any exposure in the capital markets.  Well, this is some of that. This is simply pulling ahead some debt that's going to mature, calling that potentially when [ph] its economic and doing a little more financing for that. It's a little bit of bad news for this year. So it's one of those choices that helps you in the next year and 2. Well, that's a nice one. And then there is a list at the bottom there that talks about operations and quality. There are so many things that we can do to be better for our customers that aren't necessarily in our rate cases and aren't necessarily in our basic plans. But we'll do those. And I'll just give you 1 example. Patti has talked and I have talked a lot about the Consumers Energy way. Well, sometimes it takes a little bit of money to bring in the talent to help you make these changes in your processes to the better ways of doing things. So this gives us a little more resource to do some of that work even sooner than we plan to do, so that we can get ahead of the game that improves on our quality, improves on our delivery, improves on our cost and makes us a healthier better company for you, but importantly, for our customers. And then, the reason I picked the third one last, it's sort of what happens towards the end of the year. We get a choice of how much money can we put into our company foundation and in [ph] low income funds, to help customers, to help the people of Michigan, to help our hometown team, quite candidly. And in some years, we have been strained, but we have a very big storm at the end of the year. And we don't have as many resources to put towards that. But in other years, we have an opportunity to catch up a little bit, put some more money into the foundation, and those are the choices we get to make towards the end of the year. So that gives you a little bit of sense on what the things are in the categories and how they can help you next year ensure that you grow in the 6%, 8% zone, which is an important commitment for us, becomes easier to do or more difficult to do as far as that goes. But in this case, it makes it little bit easier. Julien, I hope that helps. We will go to your next question.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Just real quickly if you will. Can you elaborate a little bit on what your thoughts and expectations coming out this [ph] life of Michigan deal are? Certainly [ph] we heard from your peers yesterday, but want to get your view and specifically
componenttext: Absolutely. Just real quickly if you will. Can you elaborate a little bit on what your thoughts and expectations coming out this [ph] life of Michigan deal are? Certainly [ph] we heard from your peers yesterday, but want to get your view and specifically can you comment on what kind of rate, what's the ballpark, and to the extent which that rate may be higher than what you're seeing out there in MISO capacity [ph] would then also bode well for your pricing on your DIG assets to the extent which folks might want to contract with local merchant asset and set of the things, the capacity charge under that construct.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- great question, Julien. There's a lot of things in flight right now with das the MISO filing and what the implications are. So, I will try and break it down a little bit and then answer completely your question. So first of all, MISO is filing with
componenttext: So -- great question, Julien. There's a lot of things in flight right now with das the MISO filing and what the implications are. So, I will try and break it down a little bit and then answer completely your question. So first of all, MISO is filing with somewhere around November 1st. There is opportunity for 3-year forward looking option and we think that's an important addition to Michigan for all of MISO but it definitely is important given our hybrid regulatory construct. Therefore, their filing has a provision for what's called the prevailing state compensation mechanism which  the state worked with MISO to establish in order for the state to have an alternative in the event that the forward showing option and our forward-looking capacity shows shortfall. So in the event of a shortfall, typically the auction will go simply to and that would set the price. So to your question on prices, yes, the capacity prices would go up just with the auction. But if Michigan sees a -- look at shortfall, then they can implement the prevailing state compensation mechanism, which requires then the alternative energy suppliers to show that they have owned contracted capacity for the subsequent 3 planning years. And then their customers pay a capacity charge that the MPSC will have the authority to set. And so, obviously, that charge has an impact on the alternative energies customers, but what we think is fair about that, is that if additional capacity is required, then the people who are requiring it are actually paying for it versus our bundled customers. So it protects our full bundled customers because we know that we'll have adequate supply to serve our customers. Now from a DIG perspective, I will let Tom address what the implications for DIG might be of that MISO option.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Naturally, the more people have to turn to find those resources, now they can't get, I will call it a free ride. But I mean that in a very constructive and a complementary way. But they can't get a free ride.  They have got to go secure their capacity. Bu
componenttext: Naturally, the more people have to turn to find those resources, now they can't get, I will call it a free ride. But I mean that in a very constructive and a complementary way. But they can't get a free ride.  They have got to go secure their capacity. But there is only so many places to go capacity in Zone 7 and nearby zones. So obviously that could help and that fits in with why we set this layering in strategy. We try not to be too greedy, thinking that we stay out of the capacity markets. All of a sudden we can get everything at peak price. We're trying to layering it and just recently we layered in. I mentioned in the text. A little more good news. We did little bit more capacity sales above $4 month. So that's an opportunity that would help. But don't forget, DIG can also be just an excellent backup to our own utility if there is a need for that capacity and that's another reason why we haven't committed all of it so far. Thanks, Julien.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Julien I'll just add one more implication for utility in the event of this implementation. If the alternative energy supplier can't secure additional capacity then it defaults to and the MPSC can direct the utility to build out that capacity and
componenttext: And then Julien I'll just add one more implication for utility in the event of this implementation. If the alternative energy supplier can't secure additional capacity then it defaults to and the MPSC can direct the utility to build out that capacity and those charges will be assigned to those alternative energy suppliers. So, that is definitely a potential. Now all of this -- the timing of all this, the filing for MISO is November of this year. We think there won't be a final ruling from FERC until 2017 and that implies that it won't be available -- the earliest will be available for you be in the 2018 auction, which is actually for the 2021, '22 planning years. So, there is a lot of time and a lot of things that can change between here and there. But we know why MISO is motivated because they are concerned about the reliability, long-term and transparency of the supply and we agree with their concern. I will reiterate though that our plan and our CapEx forward plans do not require that this MISO provision be in place. We require that the energy law be passed. We really are in a position where our plan is solid with or without either the energy law or the MISO tariff approval.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Just to be clear, your base plan in the growth rate don't necessarily rely on or expect significant improvement in financial performance of DIG. So when I look at Slide 14, and you've said this before, so I just want to make sure it's still the case. That extent potential theoretical expansion in revenues is not necessary if you to achieve your growth targets correct?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It definitely is not. What you see in yellow that slide is all the ability to create more headroom. We do not need any of that to meet our growth targets starting next year at 6% 8%.
componenttext: It definitely is not. What you see in yellow that slide is all the ability to create more headroom. We do not need any of that to meet our growth targets starting next year at 6% 8%.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I go a little bit further the field and ask a question as the Palisades nuclear contract. Strikes me that when that contract was initially signed, power prices were in a totally different planet than they are today. And it looks like that MISO power p
componenttext: Can I go a little bit further the field and ask a question as the Palisades nuclear contract. Strikes me that when that contract was initially signed, power prices were in a totally different planet than they are today. And it looks like that MISO power prices are significantly lower than what you are going to be paying over time, power coming from that asset. When you think about both the energy and the capacity that you're getting from Palisades, is there a theoretical construct where it would be in the best interest of the customers to restructure or buy out that contract?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're always very good with your analysis, but this is a subject that we actually can't talk about today and I hope you will appreciate that.
componenttext: You're always very good with your analysis, but this is a subject that we actually can't talk about today and I hope you will appreciate that.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Ali Agha of SunTrust.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Ali Agha of SunTrust.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at the weather normalized electric sales through the 9 months, it appearss they're up 0.5%. Does the 1% target for the year still looks good or what should we be assuming for the year?
componenttext: Looking at the weather normalized electric sales through the 9 months, it appearss they're up 0.5%. Does the 1% target for the year still looks good or what should we be assuming for the year?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's good. It really does look good. I know you can see the pieces there. When you look at the pieces, I call residential up half a point and commercial down half a point for the year-to-date September. I call it flat. I just watch those out even though n
componenttext: It's good. It really does look good. I know you can see the pieces there. When you look at the pieces, I call residential up half a point and commercial down half a point for the year-to-date September. I call it flat. I just watch those out even though net those numbers are positive to earnings. You see the industry sides up about 2% and we see some good information that is flowing through production plans that people have for the rest of the year and we're quite comfortable with assuming that residential and commercial will still be flattish. We're not going to try to predict up or down either way and we still think the industrial size is going to be up about 2.5% giving us a good 1% growth. I will give you a little color. We have seen some pipelines in other utilities, not us, but other utilities, doing pretty well and we watch the manufacturing side and chemicals and plastics doing very well, nice oil prices and gas prices. They are able to do good business here from Michigan. And even on the automotive side continues to be robust. Now on the negative side, we have seen some of the steel fabrication businesses and companies struggling a little bit. So some of that mineral side and steel fabrication not doing as well. But net-net some nice upticks in the factor and we get a chance to look at where people are scheduling their production for the rest of the year and things are going to do we feel pretty comfortable about where we're.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Tom, remind me is that sort of the run rate you use as going forward roughly 1% annual growth?
componenttext: And, Tom, remind me is that sort of the run rate you use as going forward roughly 1% annual growth?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We probably wouldn't say that. We're so dog unconservative that we like to tell you just think somewhere between flat to 1% growth. That's how we plan the future. Because that's how we look at our business. We try to get a sense that low and you heard my
componenttext: We probably wouldn't say that. We're so dog unconservative that we like to tell you just think somewhere between flat to 1% growth. That's how we plan the future. Because that's how we look at our business. We try to get a sense that low and you heard my story many times about my experiences back at Fordham, why that pays out, because if you're wrong and it's a little bit higher than your think, that's a helpful thing as you go through in given year. If you're wrong, and it's lower, then that's struggle. You got to do things that you might not have planned to do to make your commitment to your customers and your commitment to your investors. So we rather be on the conservative side. So I just top of my head I would like to think when we run numbers, we run them from flat to 1 and anywhere in that zone, we feel pretty good.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Separately, when you benchmark your cost versus your DIG group, where do you think you are. Are you in the top quartile, second quartile. I mean, where are you in terms of benchmarking what all you have done so far?
componenttext: Yes. Separately, when you benchmark your cost versus your DIG group, where do you think you are. Are you in the top quartile, second quartile. I mean, where are you in terms of benchmarking what all you have done so far?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say, total cost were in top quartile. Those structural changes that we've made, the long-term cost savings that we put in place, puts us in total. However, where we see the big opportunity is in distribution operations, both gas and electric,
componenttext: Yes. I would say, total cost were in top quartile. Those structural changes that we've made, the long-term cost savings that we put in place, puts us in total. However, where we see the big opportunity is in distribution operations, both gas and electric, are still middle of the pack. And so our pursuit of the great customer experience and low cost structure really we feel like that's where a lot of our headroom is. That's where we're working so hard on our process improvements.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. Last question. I know in both the case rate cases you get for the investment recovery mechanism. Previously the staff and the commissioned hasn't been very supportive of that. Any signs that this time around they are thinking differently or anythin
componenttext: I see. Last question. I know in both the case rate cases you get for the investment recovery mechanism. Previously the staff and the commissioned hasn't been very supportive of that. Any signs that this time around they are thinking differently or anything you can point to?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've had a good luck with our gas enhanced infrastructure replacement program, which is essentially an investment recovery mechanism on our gas business. And so I think that's earned some trust and respect with the commissioned. I think they're mor
componenttext: Well, we've had a good luck with our gas enhanced infrastructure replacement program, which is essentially an investment recovery mechanism on our gas business. And so I think that's earned some trust and respect with the commissioned. I think they're more open to it. Their biggest concern is infrastructure reliability in the state. Post Flint our commission is very adamant that not on our watch where we have and other infrastructure crisis related to the utilities. And so it makes the conditions amenable to these investment recovery mechanisms, though they do want and they have gone on the records saying they like having annual rate cases where we can see and we can pass on cost savings. So I think it's opportunity to continue to grow those investments recovery mechanisms but not necessarily get a flat rider on capital where will don't have to go in for rate cases.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Travis Miller from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Travis Miller from Morgan Stanley.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering when you talk about this between the cost savings that you guys are realizing in the midway and being able to keep customer bills either lower or from rising faster. Wondering if you could kind of give us a sense of how much of that cost s
componenttext: I was wondering when you talk about this between the cost savings that you guys are realizing in the midway and being able to keep customer bills either lower or from rising faster. Wondering if you could kind of give us a sense of how much of that cost savings you're seeing right now, $0.32 from the 9 months or even the future cost savings would go back to that customer, that is, through lower bills or through slower rising bills?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: 100%. And here is a plan behind that. In the short period of time where we might have a cost-reduction this year that clearly will have an impact on their business and our results, right. We look for those annual rate cases that Patti just talked about. A
componenttext: 100%. And here is a plan behind that. In the short period of time where we might have a cost-reduction this year that clearly will have an impact on their business and our results, right. We look for those annual rate cases that Patti just talked about. And it's one of the key features of the annual rate case. Primarily, it's too collect on the capital investment that we're making for customers, but it's also our to give back to our customers to our O&M cost-reduction. But the lag is just from the period that there is to the next rate case. So we'll share that with them. So we set as a goal on our base rates to try to keep that growth at or below the rate of inflation. Though pick your number everyone has a different really inflation number, but let's just say it's 2%, we can stay under that 2% and that means those base rates are going up. They are going down negatively on the real basis. So that's our goal and we're constantly doing that work to share with them. Now I grant you it gives us more headroom so that we can do more of that capital investments, which does grow the business for earnings. Is that your question.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Ridzon of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Ridzon of KeyBanc.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you kind of give your view on what's happening in the legislature and what we're going to expect before year end?
componenttext: Can you kind of give your view on what's happening in the legislature and what we're going to expect before year end?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You bet.  So I'm sure  you have seen a little bit of the press that's been out in the last week or so. The Michigan Chamber has now endorsed the bill package and that is allowing us for some more momentum and there has been a compromise on the portfolio s
componenttext: You bet.  So I'm sure  you have seen a little bit of the press that's been out in the last week or so. The Michigan Chamber has now endorsed the bill package and that is allowing us for some more momentum and there has been a compromise on the portfolio standard at 15% for 2021, that's bringing some more Democrats on board.  Therefore there seems to be quite a bit of momentum. However, we see momentum before. So we really are cautiously optimistic. the senate leader -- majority sender leader, and Mike, the energy chair out of the senate, are working hard towards a vote the postelection. With the proper momentum and a good vote count, they will take that vote and potentially moving it then into the house. So there is a lot of things that would have to come to fruition to get it to pass into the house. But with the right momentum and bipartisan support and the support of the Michigan chamber, it's more likely I would say than ever. But I still put out on 50-50 that it gets done before year end. And as you know, Paul, we continue to reiterate, our plan doesn't require the law, but we think it's a good policy for Michigan. We think it's important to energy resource supply be transparent and that the cost allocations be fair for new and additional capacity. So, this suite of bill does that work and does a good job of it. And we are supportive of our it. But again, our plan doesn't count on it and it doesn't require it.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And none of the compromises that have been made or I should say all the compromises has been embedded with the governor. Are you still okay with it?
componenttext: And none of the compromises that have been made or I should say all the compromises has been embedded with the governor. Are you still okay with it?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The administration has been very supportive. They have concern about resource adequacy in Michigan particularly for those -- for the. power provided by the alternative energy suppliers. They have real frustration that it is not transparent whether
componenttext:
Yes. The administration has been very supportive. They have concern about resource adequacy in Michigan particularly for those -- for the.
 power provided by the alternative energy suppliers. They have real frustration that it is not transparent whether that power is coming from and the administration and the commission and the utilities have been very clear that we want to make sure that it's transparent, that we have adequate supplier for the whole state. We know we have adequate supply for our customers. We want to make sure that the alternative energy suppliers also have adequate supply one way or another for their customers.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Russo of Thalmann.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Russo of Thalmann.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked and answered, but I'm just curious that the senate bill for 37 that was just referenced, would that change your capital budget either by size or mix of investments?
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked and answered, but I'm just curious that the senate bill for 37 that was just referenced, would that change your capital budget either by size or mix of investments?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't think so. It's really -- our CapEx plan, and as you saw in our slides, our generation strategy is smaller and smaller bets. We want to make sure we want to build for necessary load, that we're focused on our diverse portfolio, that can do just as
componenttext: We don't think so. It's really -- our CapEx plan, and as you saw in our slides, our generation strategy is smaller and smaller bets. We want to make sure we want to build for necessary load, that we're focused on our diverse portfolio, that can do just as load shifts and so that we can make quicker, smaller bets rather than long, long term big bets. So, there's nothing in the provisions to the law that would change that strategy.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Andy Levi with Capital Advisors.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andy Levi with Capital Advisors.

componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And just on the bigger picture. If Palisades contracts was seized or just that, how many megawatts I guess -- just remind us how many megawatts that would be.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttextpreview: But I will say this generally about our capacity planning strategy. We have alternative options and when PPAs to come off and that are -- we have a couple we have many PPAs and as they retire and we decide whether we're going to renegotiate those PPAs or
componenttext: But I will say this generally about our capacity planning strategy. We have alternative options and when PPAs to come off and that are -- we have a couple we have many PPAs and as they retire and we decide whether we're going to renegotiate those PPAs or replace them, we do have options to bring in, to do more bilaterals with other energy suppliers or to build new capacity incremental renewables, more demand response and energy efficiency. We're doing a lot of obviously capacity planning to make sure that we have adequate supply for all for customers for all the years to come and it's an exciting time because we have a lot of smaller bet options that can provide for very diverse portfolio for serving our customers and that frees up investments room and our energy -- electric distribution system and gas business where we have significant investment requirements. So, we really have a good balanced approach right now.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the MISO study that state requested, really has several components. One is the feasibility of connecting the upper, which is not our service territories. Zone 2 in the MISO zone to Saint Mary -- between Saint Mary and Ontario. And then looking at conne
componenttext: So the MISO study that state requested, really has several components. One is the feasibility of connecting the upper, which is not our service territories. Zone 2 in the MISO zone to Saint Mary -- between Saint Mary and Ontario. And then looking at connecting the UP and lower Peninsula through an existing transmission project in Gaylord or starting a larger gas plant constructed up north, somewhere up in the UP. So it's a variety of studies and they are all pointing to 1 situation that's to be correct and that's a resource adequacy issues because of our regulatory  construct in Michigan, there is a loophole up in the UP that has caused a major cost shift up there and so they are trying to figure out a way to better serve the people of the upper Peninsula. We participate to the extent that we're energy experts and the governor relies one us for our input and insights, but the study that they've requested from MISO really will help frame up the situation, I would say, and when it's complete, we'll certainly obviously take a look and see what the options are.
